Results.Body: The main purpose of this website is to help you start your software engineering career. We're going to get you an internship, we're going to get you a job, and we're going to get you PAID. I understand that the current job market is difficult to get into, not just for UNCW students, but for computer science majors as a whole. This site contains information that will help you in your job search and in your academic career. I also included some other more general topics throughout the website that I thought you might like. If you want me to add a section or want me to elaborate or add more information to an existing section, please don't hesitate to Contact me.

Results.Header: Why should you listen to me?
Results.Body: I am a recent UNCW computer science alumni and I'm currently working as a Software Engineer at IBM in Research Triangle Park. During college I had two SWE internships, one at USAA and the other at a startup company called Amotions, Inc. I've also received a couple other full-time and internship offers as well. My situation is somewhat rare for a UNCW alumni and I want to help get you in the same boat, if that's something you're interested in. So far, I've successfully helped a friend of mine at UNCW (class of 2025) get a SWE internship at USAA and I feel like I've developed pretty good job-searching strategies over the years. I think you would find some of these techniques and strategies useful, so I've shared them fairly in depth throughout this website. As mentioned earlier, if you need any help with anything please do not hesitate to contact me. Definitely don't hesitate to spam me with questions, I'd be more than happy to answer all of them to the best of my ability.

You can search for a page by typing it's name in the search bar. The results shown are pages that's name matches the search query. If you want to search for a term within a page, type the term in the search bar and then click return/enter. You'll be taken to a page showing views which contain the search term. You can't be hovering over the search bar when you press enter/return to avoid a menu accidentally expanding. Just move your cursor to the side when you start typing. This isn't an issue when the sidebar is displayed.

You can view the source code in this GitHub Repository. This web application is written in Vue.js and is currently being hosted on GitHub pages. In case something happens to this website, you can also download the source code by clicking &here&(/download/Practice.docx).

Results.Name: USAA
Results.Location: Plano, Texas or San Antonio, Texas
Results.Tips: The official name of this SWE position is "IT Intern". Set up notifications via handshake for USAA if you're interested. I think the San Antonio summer application comes out in early-mid September. The Plano one comes out in early-mid October. Apply as soon as the application comes out and I think your chances of getting the job will be pretty high. I could help you through the interview process, and if you did your internship in Plano I could help you with housing. You could also set job alerts using this link -> Here. Go to the bottom section of the page titled "Join our talent community" and enter your information to subscribe to their job alert mailing list. Also the return offer rate for full-time positions at USAA is VERY high (~85%) so keep that in mind through the process. This is a very fun, easy, low-stress internship with lots of great learning and networking opportunities. You'll meet a lot of other college kids in the same boat as you, which I think is good.

Results.desc: These are tips I have for getting a software engineering job.

Results.Name: Possible Career Path
Results.Description: This is a possible career path you could take inspiration from.
Results.Career Path: In summer 2024 try to get a job at Datacor, Inc. or nCino. The job at "Datacor, inc." is remote and pays. If interested contact me using the form, I know a guy., During your junior year work as a TAC Student Technician., Apply to USAA in early September or Early October for summer 2025. The position is called "IT Intern". Look out for the one in Plano, TX., Go to the Career fair in September and apply for Pearson as a backup., During the second semester of your junior year work as an intern at Amotions, Inc. and get credit for CSC 498., Work at USAA in summer 2025 (preferably Plano so I can help you with housing)., Graduate early in December 2025 and start applying to "reach" companies.

Results.Name: Apply to USAA
Results.Description: The application for USAA opens in early September for summer 2025. Keep an eye for it and apply as soon as it comes out. I'll help you through the (very easy) interview process. I helped a guy in the grade above you at UNCW get this internship. I also saw another person in the same grade get this internship. USAA is great company and not too difficult to get into.
Results.Interview Process: You apply in early-mid September or October for the "IT Intern" position. It's just a regular software engineering internship. We used Java and React.js mostly, A couple days after you apply you should get a super easy coding assessment to complete, After that you should get a short easy phone interview, About a week later you should get an invitation to a 1 hour zoom interview. It's super easy behavioral questions and like 2 EXTREMELY easy short basic coding questions., After your interview you should receive an offer in like 2-3 weeks., This probably more long and rigorous than it actually is. It's like 3 relatively short tasks.

Results.Name: Apply to Pearson
Results.Description: Pearson typically comes to the UNCW Career fair in September. You could apply there if you wanted.
Results.Interview Process: Just one super basic interview. They didn't ask me to write any code

Results.Name: Apply to Amotions
Results.Description: Fully remote startup in California. You could use this to get 3 credit hours for CSC 498.
Results.Interview Process: Just one interview. We just looked at personal projects I had made, talked about what technologies I was familiar with, and did an EXTREMELY easy coding problem in python.

Results.Name: Do NOT listen to professors
Results.Description: I've had multiple comp sci professors basically say they're going to get people in the class an internships and they never follow through on their promises. Don't expect them to help you.

Results.Name: Apply Early
Results.Description: If you're applying to jobs in summer 2025 or January 2026, you should start applying in August. Don't wait until the last minute to start applying for jobs.

Results.Name: Set job alerts on LinkedIn and Handshake
Results.Description: Job alerts are emails that will be sent to you when a company has new job opportunities. These allow you to know what jobs are open and what companies are hiring. I also believe that the sooner you apply the better. I'd imagine a hiring manager would look mostly the first applications sent in, and not the 1000 others sent in 3 weeks after the job opening was posted.

Results.Name: Be Timely
Results.Description: If you see a job posting you're interested in, apply as soon as possible. Don't wait 3 weeks before applying because probably a ton of other people will have applied by then or the posting might've closed.

Results.Name: Be Patient
Results.Description: Being patient is key when you're applying for jobs. I have multiple examples.
Results.Examples: I applied for the Software Engineer I position at Cisco on August 2nd, 2023. I didn't hear back until February 14th, 2024 at which point I was already working at IBM., It took me about a month to receive an offer from Pearson after my interview. I thought they had ghosted me., Completing the USAA interview process took me about a month., I did my virtual interview with the NSA on June 26th, 2023. I didn't receive an offer/hear back until September 19th, 2023. Totally out of the blue., I got an offer from IBM 2 days after my second interview, so there are exceptions to the rule I guess. IBM's interview process was very fast and easy imo.

Results.Name: Be Consistent
Results.Description: Apply early and apply frequently. When I was looking for an internship in Fall 2023 for the summer, I would literally just go back to my apartment and apply to jobs for like a hour every single day.

Results.Name: Don't get Discouraged
Results.Description: I must have applied to literally like a 1,000 companies when I was looking for internships and full-time jobs. I was rejected countless times, usually by companies much less "prestigious" then USAA, the NSA, and IBM.

Results.Name: Don't let rejection get you down
Results.Description: Adding to the last point, keep being persistent and trying. Just because you got rejected from a position at a smaller company, doesn't mean a bigger, more prestigious company won't hire you. I got reject by like 1000 small, obscure companies before IBM hired me.

Results.Name: Graduate Early
Results.Description: The competition won't be as intense if you start applying to jobs that start in January. If you graduate in May you'll be going up against a much larger applicant pool.

Results.Name: Look for Entry-Level Roles
Results.Description: This is pretty intuitive, but looks for jobs that are entry-level, junior, new grad, etc.

Results.Name: Go to the Career Fair
Results.Description: The UNCW computer science career fair is typically held in late September and February. I'd recommend going as companies interested in hiring UNCW students will be there.

Results.Name: Make your Resume Look Good
Results.Description: Having a clean, well-organized, and professional resume can have a positive impact and help you stand out. I've had hiring managers in the past tell me how much they liked my resume. See here for the template I use.

Results.Name: Check your UNCW Email Frequently
Results.Description: People from the UNCW computer science department sometimes send out SWE job opportunities in the Wilmington area. In particularly Ron Vetter and Shauna White.

Results.Name: Visit Professor Websites
Results.Description: Professor websites typically have upcoming research opportunities that you can contact them about. An example would be Dr. Layman's GitHub Pages website.

Results.Name: Let Me Know If You Have Questions
Results.Description: If you have any questions about jobs or if you think I can help you in any way, do NOT hesitate to contact me. I'd be more than happy to help.

Results.desc: These are tips I have for preparing for and participating in an interview. These are mostly common software engineering topics I was asked about in interviews.

Results.tip: Study the 4 concepts of OOP. Polymorphism, Abstraction, Inheritance, Encapsulation
Study basic algorithms and data structures. You don't need to memorize them. But know the basics of how they work.
You probably won't have to code them, but know the basics of stacks, linked-lists, binary search, queues, etc.
Prepare to discuss your previous programming/software engineering experience. Even it's just school, discuss the topics you've learned and projects you've worked on.
Know the basics of GitHub and Git. At least be able to explain the general idea of those concepts.
Gain a super basic understanding of Kubernetes, docker, pods, and containers. Look into certifications. It would be very good to learn.
Know the super basic concepts of Amazon Web Services and Cloud computing. An AWS certification would probably look good.
Know basic security practices (I'd strongly recommend taking CSC 351).
Know what HTTP and HTTPS are. CSC 351 discusses this concept which is another reason I'd recommend taking it.
Know the basics of databases. Like what's MongoDB, NoSQL, relational databases, etc.
Know the basics of Memory management in Java and C++. Particularly Garbage collection.
Know basic testing testing practices. Know the basics of the following: Unit tests, White box testing, Black box testing, JUnit, etc.
Have a basic understanding of C pointers and reference operators
Look at the job description and see what skills are listed. Study those as well.
Obviously come on time and don't be late.
Appear enthusiastic to be there and about what's being discussed
Come well-groomed and act professional.
Come prepared with follow up questions for the interviewer. This will help demonstrate your interest and knowledge.

Results.desc: This is a possible career path you could consider taking.

Results.advice: In summer 2024 try to get a job at Datacor, Inc. or nCino. The job at "Datacor, inc." is remote and pays. If interested, tell me using the form, I know a guy.
In September and October 2024, start applying for jobs in Summer 2025. Apply at companies such as USAA, Pearson, etc.
Your junior year you could work as a TAC Student Worker Technician while on campus. See the Where To Apply page for more details.
Your second semester junior year you could work as a SWE intern at Amotions, Inc. and get credit for CSC 498.
In Summer 2025 you could work at USAA or some other bigger company after you've gained more experience.
You could graduate in December 2025 and look for jobs that start in the winter when it's less competitive.
This is just a possible path. Obviously you can do whatever you want.

Results.Body: To keep it simple, LinkedIn is like Instagram for jobs. It's a place where you can apply to jobs, follow companies, and create job alerts. There's also a social side to LinkedIn. You can follow your friends to see their job updates and you can create a profile of your own. Job recruiters will typically view your profile to see if you're a good candidate for a job, so try to make it nice and professional. You can also also "connect" with other people and react to their posts, make comments, etc. I would definitely consider LinkedIn an extremely important part of your job search and definitely something worth checking out.

Results.desc: These are tips on how to setup a profile on LinkedIn. It's pretty straight forward.

Results.instruction: Before you do anything else, change your profile viewing settings. LinkedIn will notify people that you viewed their profile if you don't change this setting. Go to this link and select "private mode". Press the back button when you're done.
Go to the LinkedIn home page, just to start from the beginning.
In the upper right corner, click on your profile picture that says "Me" under it. Press the "View Profile" button.
To the right of your profile picture. Click on the pencil icon and fill out all required fields for your intro.
After that click the "Add profile section". Under the "Core" menu option press "Add about".
Once the "Add About" input box opens, write a description about yourself summarizing your experience, passions, skills, goals, etc.
After that click the "Add profile section" again. Under the "Core" menu option press "Add position".
Once the "Add Experience" input box opens, fill out all fields for your position. Make sure to add skills used and a description, despite those fields being optional. Press "Save" when you're done.
Now that you have one position added, you should see an "Experience" section now. Add more positions by pressing the plus symbol.
Go back to the top of the page and press "Add profile section" again. Under "Core" select "Add education".
I'd recommend adding both Weddington High School and UNCW. Adding your high school will help you find people you went to high school with and show you went right to college after you graduated.
Go back to the top of the page and press "Add profile section" again. Under "Additional" select "Add volunteer experience".
Fill out any Volunteering experience you've done.
Go back to the top of the page and press "Add profile section" again. Under "Additional" select "Add volunteer experience".
Add skills you're proficient in so people can see what you know how to do.
Go back to the top of the page and press "Add profile section" again. Under "Recommended" select "Add courses".
Add relevant coursework you've taken.
Go back to the top of the page and press "Add profile section" again. Under "Recommended" select "Add licenses & certifications".
Add any certifications you have. For example, if you're certified in Microsoft Excel you could add that.
After you've done all that, look up companies you're interested in working for and follow them. Also connect with people you know.
Go to the Setup Job Alerts page, to learn how to get notified about job openings about certain companies.

Results.desc: This is how to Setup Job Alerts on LinkedIn. It's pretty simple.

Results.instruction: Before you do anything, make sure you have notifications set up for job alerts using this link. I'd recommend enabling In-app, push, and email notifications for job alerts. Once you done, press the back button.
For this example, lets create a job alert for "Software Engineer" at nCino in Wilmington, North Carolina.
Go to the LinkedIn home page.
Go the search bar and type "nCino". Click on "nCino, inc" company in the suggested results. Then click the name again.
You should now be on nCino's LinkedIn page. The "Home" tab should be highlighted green under the Follow and Learn more buttons.
In the same tab bar as the "Home" tab, click the "Jobs" tab.
Right under the tabs you should see a card that says "Create job alert for nCino, Inc.". Click the "Create job alert" button on the right.
In the "Job title" field type "Software Engineer". In the "Job location" field type "Wilmington" and select "Wilmington, North Carolina, United States" from the suggested menu.
Select the workplace formats you want to work in. You can choose between On-Site, Hybrid, Remote, or a combination of all three.
After you do that press the "Create job alert" button. You should now have a job alert for Software Engineering positions at nCino, Inc. in Wilmington, NC.
Continue to do this for other companies you like
You can also do this for locations. Lets create another alert for "Software Engineer" in Atlanta.
Go to the LinkedIn home page.

At the top click the "Jobs". Then go to the search bar and type "Software Engineer". In the filed next to it that says "United States" type "Atlanta" and select it from the suggestion menu. Then click enter.
You should now be at the result screen. Above the results you should see a blue bar that says "Software Engineer in Atlanta, Georgia, United States" in white text
Next to the white text, toggle the "Set Alert" button. The title bar should turn from blue to white and you should get a pop up saying you're alert has been created.
You have now created a job alert for Software Engineering positions in Atlanta, Georgia.
You can create job alerts for any position, company, location, etc.

Results.desc: These are tips I have for how to use LinkedIn effectively and have a good experience.

Results.Tip: Tip 1
Results.Name: Setup Job Alerts
Results.Explanation: Job alerts are used to notify you about new job openings.
Results.Instructions: Open the LinkedIn app, Search for a company you'd like to work for (Ex. nCino), Go to the jobs tab -> https://www.linkedin.com/company/ncino-inc-/Jobs/, Press the "Create job alert" button., In the job title field type "Software Engineer", For job location type "Wilmington, North Carolina", When you're done click the blue job alert button.

Results.Tip: Tip 2
Results.Name: Set Viewing Options
Results.Explanation: This will determine what people see when you view their profile. I'd recommend private mode.
Results.Instructions: Go to this link -> https://www.linkedin.com/mypreferences/d/profile-viewing-options, Select "Private mode" (or whatever mode you want people to see when you view their profile), Click the back button once done.

Results.Tip: Tip 3
Results.Name: Setup Your Profile
Results.Explanation: Set up your profile so recruiters can learn more about you and your work experience. Go to this page for details.

Results.Tip: Tip 4
Results.Name: Setup Notification Settings
Results.Instructions: Go to this LinkedIn page -> https://www.linkedin.com/mypreferences/d/categories/notifications. To set up your notification settings, I'd recommend having all notifications on for job alerts.

Results.Tip: Tip 5
Results.Name: Connect With People
Results.Instructions: To connect with people simply look their name up in the search bar on the feed page., Click their profile in the results., Near the top of their profile click the blue "Connect" button.

Results.Tip: Tip 6
Results.Name: Try LinkedIn Premium for Free
Results.Explanation: LinkedIn premium isn't worth the money in my opinion. However, LinkedIn does give you one month free, so I'd definitely recommend trying it out and coming to your own conclusions.

Results.Tip: Tip 7
Results.Name: Try to Get 500+ Connections on LinkedIn
Results.Explanation: Doing this will help boost you in the algorithm, look good to recruiters, and help expand your network.

Results.Tip: Tip 8
Results.Name: Use the "People" Tab
Results.Explanation: If you go to a companies page, and go to the "People" tab you can see information about employees who work there. This information includes what employees went to your school, how many work in engineering, etc. That‚Äôs how I got a lot of information on this site.
Results.Instructions: For this example lets use nCino, Inc., Go to the People Tab of the company website., Look around the page to learn more about the people from the company., Note: In my opinion, the People tab looks better and is more intuitive to use on the mobile app.

Results.desc1: These are classes and professors I really enjoyed taking or have heard good things about.
Results.desc2: These are classes I would recommend taking for various reasons.
Results.desc3: These are Professors I would recommend taking whenever possible.

Results.Name: HST 101: Western Civilization I
Results.Title: Western Civilization I
Results.Description: This class was incredible. It was basically just the professor telling us stories about ancient history the entire time. The periods covered were predominantly Ancient Mesopotamia, Egypt, Greece, Rome, Muslim Empire, Viking, and Old England. The class was 3 super easy essays, 4 tests (all the same length), and a couple quizzes throughout. Tragically, it seems like Dr. Ellithorpe is now teaching at the University of South Florida. However, I'd definitely watch out to see if he comes back and take it with him if possible.

Results.Name: CSC 351: Applied Software Security
Results.Title: Applied Software Security
Results.Description: This class is SUPER easy, I ended with a 100. The grades are 4 short/relatively easy coding assignments, a take home coding exam for the final you have a week to finish, and online take home quizzes throughout. The topics covered are super relevant to real world software engineering. The information I learned from this class came up a lot in job interviews so I‚Äôd definitely recommend it. Super easy A. Also Dr. Layman gives very generous extra credit.

Results.Name: CSC 498: Internship in Computer Science
Results.Title: Internship in Computer Science
Results.Description: This class is a great and easy way to get 3 credit hours. You can take this "class" if you get a computer science internship. All you have to do in this class is write one paragraph a week about what you did in your internship and at the end you present your poster at the computing showcase. The "presentation" is extremely easy and you just stand by your poster. I only had like two people come up to me the entire time to ask me about my poster. You don't present in front of a group. The class is pass/fail and you can't sign for it using seanet. Email Mrs. White (turners@uncw.edu) to express your interest and she'll help you sign up. Note that your internship supervisor should say you're working 15 hours a week to get the full 3 credit hours. Here's a picture of my computing showcase poster.

Results.Name: MUS 115: Music in Society
Results.Title: Music in Society
Results.Description: This is the easiest class I've taken since like 1st grade. All we would do is open note quizzes that's questions just were copied and pasted facts directly from the slides with a word left out. The quizzes were open notes/internet as well. We also did 2 extremely short easy concert review papers. You could tell he seriously didn't care about grading stuff or making the class hard.  Unfortunately Dr. Fife seems to now be teaching at Winthrop University. I'd still keep an eye out, maybe he'll come back. Also I'm sure this class would be pretty easy no matter the format or professor.

Results.Name: ARH 201: Ancient Art and Archaeology
Results.Title: Ancient Art and Archaeology
Results.Description: This is overall a pretty easy class. There are like 8 quizzes you can do as many times as you want at home. There are also like 4 online tests you take at home. While this class is technically in-person, attendance isn't mandatory and you can just do all the exams online.

Results.Name: PSY 105: General Psychology
Results.Title: General Psychology
Results.Description: I never took this class, but I feel having a good, basic understanding of psychology would help with any degree.

Results.Name: EBD 380: Entrepreneurship
Results.Title: Entrepreneurship
Results.Description: I never took this class, but I feel like it would be good to have some level of knowledge on entrepreneurship. Also, I think this class is required for a Business Administration degree.

Results.Name: PED 150: Beginning Sailing
Results.Title: Beginning Sailing
Results.Description: I never took this class, but it teaches the theory, navigation rules, equipment, and basic skills of sailing. I thought you might find that enjoyable as an elective.

Results.Name: Dr. Xiaojie Hou
Results.Description: As a computer science major at UNCW you have to take calculus II. Dr. Hou makes it extremely easy to pass/get a good grade in his class. Despite the class being in person, he lets you take all the quizzes and tests at home/online. Also the questions from the quizzes are basically pulled directly from the homework. The tests are also basically the exact same as the study guide. I got an A- in this class because of him. 10/10 would recommend.

Results.Name: Dr. Lucas Layman
Results.Description: Dr. Layman's classes are lit. They are typically very easy and he gives a LOT of extra credit. He also teaches a lot of information that's useful in the real world. He's also pretty funny and friendly.

Results.Name: Dr. Corey Ellithorpe
Results.Description: Dr. Ellithorpe GOATED. He's a god-tier story teller and teaches history in a very theatrical way. There were times I was literally borderline shaking cause of how exciting some of the stories were. He would also sometimes end the class on a cliff-hanger which was always fun. Tragically, it seems like now he's teaching at the University of South Florida. Hopefully he'll come back.

Results.Name: Dr. Curry Guinn
Results.Description: UPDATE: tragically Dr. Guinn has moved to the University of Colorado, so you'll have to take the class with another professor. Dr. Guinn is a great professor and very nice wholesome person. I went to his office hours once and he acted like I was his childhood best friend who he hadn't seen in like 30 years. He's also more than happy to help you out if you needed it. Would recommend.

Results.Name: CSC 133: Discrete Mathematical Structures
Results.Title: Discrete Mathematical Structures
Results.Description: Overall I remember this being a pretty easy class. It's like fun easy puzzles. 2 tests, a final exam, and like 10 short easy homeworks. Take notes during class and study the homework and the tests should be easy.
Results.Skills: A very small amount of Python
Results.Tips: Study the homework before tests and take good notes in class.
Results.Grading: Homework - 10%, Quizzes - 15%, 3 Tests - 60%, Final Exam - 15%

Results.Name: MAT 161: Calculus with Analytical Geometry I
Results.Title: Calculus with Analytical Geometry I
Results.Description: Like 5 difficult homeworks you can work on in a group. Also Cengage completion homework. 2 tests and a final exam. He lets you have like 2 pages of notes on the tests and like 5 on the final exam (I think). While that sounds good I'd still recommend taking Dr. Xiajoue Hou instead.
Results.Grading: Exam 1 - 20%, Exam 2 - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, All Homework - 25%, Participation - 5%

Results.Name: CHM 101: General Chemistry I
Results.Title: General Chemistry I
Results.Description: Standard chemistry class. You do a ton of Aleks homework worth like 30% of your final grade. There are 3 tests and a final exam. The final exam can replace all 3 test grades.
Results.Grading: Exam 1 - 15%, Exam 2 - 15%, Exam 3 - 15%, Online Homework - 30%, Final Exam - 25%

Results.Name: CHML 101: General Chemistry Laboratory I
Results.Title: General Chemistry Laboratory I
Results.Description: Lab sessions are typically 2 hours and not that hard. You have lab once a week.
Results.Grading: Like 10 labs lowest gets dropped.

Results.Name: MAT 162: Calculus with Analytical Geometry II
Results.Title: Calculus with Analytical Geometry II
Results.Description: GOATED professor. Despite the class being in-person he lets you take all exams/quizzes at home online. I think there are 3 tests and 1 final exam. The study guides are EXACTLY like the tests. Also large amounts of cengage completion homework. I would strongly recommend this professor.
Results.Grading: He has a weird point system, not percentages. 3 exams, a final, and homework.

Results.Name: PHY 201: General Physics I
Results.Title: General Physics I
Results.Description: Like 3 regular tests and online completion homework, and a final exam. Dr. Daniel's GOATED and gave me a C for basically no reason. I definitely wouldn't recommend taking physics if you don't have to. I liked the part of this class where he described how airpods cancel noise though, it's pretty cool imo.
Results.Grading: Exam 1 - 15%, Exam 2 - 15%, Exam 3 - 15%, Homework - 15%, Labs - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, NOTE: Lowest of 3 exam grades is dropped.

Results.Name: WPA 101: Individual Physical Activity and Wellness
Results.Title: Individual Physical Activity and Wellness ONLINE LECTURE
Results.Description: Both the lecture and lab are only 1 credit hour. This is an extremely easy lecture with minimal work. I don't really remember the specifics.
Results.Grading: Weird point system. It's extremely easy, just do the work and you'll almost definitely get an A

Results.Name: WPAL 101: Power Yoga
Results.Title: Power Yoga ONLINE LAB
Results.Description: The entire grade was just watching one video a week and listing 2 new exercises from the video. Super easy class. Both the lecture and lab are only 1 credit hour.
Results.Grading: Like 1 lab a week. Just do the work and you'll almost definitely get an A

Results.Name: CSC 231: Introduction to Data Structures
Results.Title: Introduction to Data Structures
Results.Description: You learn about important data structures such as stacks, queues, linked-lists, binary search trees, etc. You also learn about algorithms like Binary Search, Merge sort, etc. and their time complexities. The tests are easy as long as you study, the labs are typically a bit more difficult.
Results.Tips: Learn how to use debug mode in PyCharm. It can very helpful when debugging data structures.
Results.Grading: Quizzes - 15%, Labs - 10% (Like 10 labs), Take Home Programming Assignments - 15% (Like 3 assignments), Test 1 - 20%, Test 2 - 20%, Final Exam - 20%

Results.Name: CSC 242: Computer Organization
Results.Title: Computer Organization
Results.Description: This was definitely one of my least favorite classes taken at UNCW. It's like converting hexadecimal and binary numbers in the beginning and then assembly code. Like 10 homeworks, 3 exams, and a final exam. She replaced our lowest test grade with the final exam grade. The final exam is pulled straight from the homework. For the tests study the homework and know how everything works.
Results.Grading: NOTE: I couldn't find the syllabus. This is from memory., 3 tests, Like 8 homeworks, Final Exam

Results.Name: CSC 302: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
Results.Title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
Results.Description: I wouldn't recommend taking this class unless you really want to have an Artificial Intelligence concentration. The class is mostly just graphs other than the 5 python coding assignments. The professor talks extremely fast and it can be difficult to get all the necessary information. The tests are also very hard and don't have much information from the slides, but you can use a cheat sheet. Overall the amount of work and difficulty of this class isn't worth it for an elective class. This class is mostly just graphs and python search algorithms. If you want to learn more about actual artificial intelligence, I'd recommend you get a certification. Also, he made us use Python version 3.6 or below in this class and it was kind of a hassle switching between the newer and older versions.
Results.Tips: Go to his office hours
Results.Grading: Midterm Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 35%, Programming assignments - 25% (5 assignments total), Written assignments - 20% (5 assignments total)

Results.Name: HST 101: Europe in the World I
Results.Title: Europe in the World I
Results.Description: This class was easily one my favorite classes I've ever taken. The title "Europe in the World I" is not a super accurate name for what you learn about in this class. Dr. Ellithorpe is an amazing professor and teaches history in a super entertaining story-telling way. There were times I was on edge of my seat borderline shaking at how exciting the stories were. Dr. Ellithorpe also understands that people are taking the class as an elective and aren't history majors, so he makes it relatively easy and fun. The grades are just quizzes, 3 easy essays, and 4 tests of the same length. The historical periods covered are the Ancient Near East and Egypt, Greece, Rome, and Medieval Europe. Tragically, Dr. Ellithorpe appears to now be working at the University of South Florida. Hopefully he'll come back to UNCW someday.
Results.Grading: Quizzes - 15% (10 Quizzes, 1.5 each), Essays - 30% (3 Essays total), Tests - 50% (4 total, 12.5 each), Attendance - 5%
Results.Tips: This class is now called HST 101: Western Civilization I, even though that's not really what we covered in class. Take a ton of notes during class.

Results.Name: OCN 250: Coasts and Society
Results.Title: Coasts and Society
Results.Description: Overall this class isn't too bad. There are two exams which contains questions that you haven't really seen before, but they still aren't too bad. The assignments are relatively short and easy. The quizzes are typically pretty straight-forward and multiple choice. At the end you have a relatively easy presentation. I think this is only online, so for the presentation I just made like a 7 slide presentation describing an Oceanography issue around the globe (Overfishing in Thailand/Marine fisheries in Thailand). I just recorded my voice speaking for a minute on each slide and I got a 100 on the project. This class is kinda mid tbh. It's easy enough for the credit it can get you, so I guess I'd recommend it.
Results.Grading: Exams - 32% (2 exams), Assignments - 24% (6 Assignments), Quizzes - 24% (Roughly 8), Coasts of the World Project - 20%

Results.Name: CHM 102: General Chemistry II
Results.Title: General Chemistry II
Results.Description: Standard chemistry class TWO. You do a ton of Aleks homework worth like 30% of your final grade. There are 3 tests and a final exam. The final exam can replace all 3 test grades.
Results.Grading: Exam 1 - 15%, Exam 2 - 15%, Exam 3 - 15%, Online Homework - 30%, Final Exam - 25%

Results.Name: CHML 102: General Chemistry Laboratory II
Results.Title: General Chemistry Laboratory II
Results.Grading: Like 10 labs lowest gets dropped.

Results.Name: CSC 331: Object-Oriented Programming and Design
Results.Title: Object-Oriented Programming and Design
Results.Description: This class is easy if you have any experience whatsoever with Java. It's like CSC 131 for Java instead of python. The labs are pretty easy as well as the tests. She lets you have a cheat sheet for the tests. For one lab you work in a group of 3. At the end you work in a group of 5 for a 10-minute long project presentation. The project is a JavaFx project written using Java, JavaFx, FXML, and SceneBuilder. JavaFx is a framework for building GUI's for Java. It adds logic to your FXML code, and you can use it to build UI components programmatically in your project, I did both in ours. I personally really like the framework and the end project was definitely my favorite programming project I did for UNCW.
Results.Grading: Homework - 10%, Test 1 - 10%, Test 2 - 10%, Final Project - 10%, Labs - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Attendance - 5%

Results.Name: CSC 340: Scientific Computing
Results.Title: Scientific Computing
Results.Description: I feel like this class varies a lot, based on what professor you take. I talked to people who took it with other professors and it sounded like a different class entirely. However, I took it online with Dr. Brittany Morago, so that's what I'll describe. There are no tests or quizzes in this class which I really liked. It's just programming assignments and math assignments. The math is like more simple calculus concepts and written mathematical computing problems. It typically explains how to do the problems in the videos so definitely watch them. The programming assignments can be challenging at times. I basically lived in her office hours that semester to ensure that I got a good grade in this class. The programming assignments are in Python and involve most image analysis algorithms using opencv and numpy. If you're struggling definitely watch her videos and go to her office hours. She helps you a lot if you go to her virtual office hours.
Results.Tips: Go to her office hours and watch the videos she posts.
Results.Grading: Homework - 40% (Roughly 16, but they're pretty short), Programming assignments - 60% (6, but they're pretty big)

Results.Name: CSC 360: Formal Languages and Computability
Results.Title: Formal Languages and Computability
Results.Description: I found this class somewhat difficult. It's like a harder a version of discrete math/history of modern computing class. Topics include finite-state machines, regex, turing machines, etc. It's like mathematical puzzles and graphs. You do basically no coding in this class except briefly using python to test regex. I also liked when the professor would discuss the history of computing, future of artificial intelligence, and other stuff like that. I would HIGHLY recommend taking this class with Dr. Curry Guinn. He's more then happy to help you with stuff and is a good teacher/nice person. Also at the end you do a writing assignment on a book about Alan Turing's life. While I would always do my work in college, I didn't read a single page of the book and still got a 100% on the assignment. I just skimmed parts of it online and used chatGPT. It's not a difficult writing assignment. Also, you take the quizzes online at home. UPDATE: tragically Dr. Guinn has moved to the University of Colorado, so you'll have to take the class with another professor.
Results.Skills: A very small amount of Python
Results.Tips: Study the homework a lot before the tests and take good notes during class. Don't rely on the slides
Results.Grading: Quizzes - 10% (Roughly 8), Homework Assignments - 25% (Roughly 8 assignments), Test 1 - 15%, Test 2 - 15%, Final Exam - 35%

Results.Name: CSC 385: Professional and Ethical Issues in Computing
Results.Title: Professional and Ethical Issues in Computing
Results.Description: This class is overall extremely easy until the end. You do basically nothing but listen to her lecture the entire semester. You have two short exams which contain questions basically directly from the slides. At the end you have a 5-10 minute (I think, mine was 6 minutes) long solo presentation about an ethical issue in computing. You also have a 5 page single spaced paper due on an ethical issue. But other than those two last assignments I found the class super easy. If you do the work you'll probably get an A with no issues.
Results.Skills: You don't code at all this class
Results.Tips: Start early on the presentation and Research Paper. Don't wait.
Results.Grading: Attendance & Participation - 20%, Presentations - 20%, Writing Assignments - 20%, Exams - 20%, Research Paper - 20%

Results.Name: CSC 498: Internship in Computer Science
Results.Title: Internship in Computer Science
Results.Description: This is a 3 credit hour class that's pass/fail. All you do is write 1 paragraph a week summarizing what you did at your internship and at the end you create a poster presentation demonstrating what you did during your internship. Note that you don't present the poster in-front of a group. You just hang it up in Congdon Hall and stand by it the entire time. I only had like 2 people come up to ask me about it during the 2-hour showcase. Also, it's just a completion grade, so it's pretty low-stress. The computing showcase is a great place to meet and talk to employers in the Wilmington area. This was my poster. I got a 100 on it.
Results.Tips: You can't sign up for this class via Seanet. Contact Shauna White (turners@uncw.edu) if you're interested.
Results.Grading: Weekly Paragraphs - 50%, Poster presentation - 50%

Results.Name: MUS 115: Music in Society
Results.Title: Music in Society
Results.Description: This is the easiest class I've taken since Elementary school. The only grades were open-note/slides tests and quizzes and like 2 one-page papers. The open notes tests and quizzes are just questions taken directly from the slides with a word left out. You were allowed to use the slides during the tests. The papers we're an extremely easy completion grade and were like 1 page long. It was a concert review and he let you just watch youtube concerts. Tragically, Dr. Fife now works at Winthrop University. Hopefully he'll come back someday.
Results.Grading: Weekly quizzes - 40%, Virtual Concert Reports - 20%, Midterm - 20%, Final Exam - 20%

Results.Name: ARH 201: Ancient Art and Archaeology
Results.Title: Ancient Art and Archaeology
Results.Description: Overall this class isn't bad. While this class is technically in-person, all the quizzes and tests are taken at home online. Also, attendance isn't required and usually like half the class doesn't show up. Some questions are the tests and quizzes are a pretty obscure, but overall it's a decent easy elective. You can also retake the quizzes as many times as you want.
Results.Grading: Quizzes - 25% (7 total), Exams - 75% (4 total)

Results.Name: CSC 351: Applied Software Security
Results.Title: Applied Software Security
Results.Description: This class teaches a lot of helpful information. A lot of these topics came up in job interviews and is just helpful to know for coding. The class itself is very easy and I found it's content interesting. You do 4 easy python programming assignments throughout and a couple easy multiple-choice online quizzes. The final-exam is an online taken-home coding assessment. In class Layman, shows many real life examples of things, and demonstrates concepts using JavaScript, html, C, Python, SQL, etc. While you don't have to write in these languages (except Python) just seeing them in use would probably be helpful in learning the basics of them. Overall an extremely easy class without that much work. Would highly recommend.
Results.Tips: Dr. Layman offers very generous extra credit, take advantage of it.
Results.Grading: Assignments - 40% (4 coding assignments), Quizzes - 45% (7 total), Final Exam - 15%

Results.Name: CSC 342: Operating Systems
Results.Title: Operating Systems
Results.Description: This class is decent overall. The programming assignments are building various parts of python operating systems simulator. The labs are practice problems for the tests and a review of what you learned in class. While they're just graded as completion, definitely still try on them to prepare yourself for the tests and have something to study beforehand.
Results.Tips: The tests problems draw heavily from the labs, so make sure to study the labs beforehand and not just focus on the slides.
Results.Grading: Programming assignments - 30% (5 assignments total), Exam 1 - 10%, Exam 2 - 10%, Exam 3 - 10%, Labs - 10%, Final Exam - 30%

Results.Name: CSC 380: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
Results.Title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
Results.Description: You don't code at all in this class. It's just graph problems related to algorithms. While this class is technically synchronous, attendance to the lectures isn't required and he records them. The homeworks draw heavily from the lectures, so make sure to watch the recordings. The tests also draw heavily from the homework so make sure you know what you're doing in that regard. Unfortunately, the tests are worth a lot, so if you get something wrong on the test it will have a somewhat large impact on your grade.
Results.Skills: You don't code at all this class
Results.Tips: Take this class with Dr. Guinn if possible. Also try and understand the homeworks and watch the lecture recordings. UPDATE: tragically Dr. Guinn has moved to the University of Colorado, so you'll have to take the class with another professor.
Results.Grading: Homework - 30% (6 Assignments), Midterm 1 - 20%, Midterm 2 - 20%, Final Exam - 30%

Results.Name: CSC 434: Programming Languages
Results.Title: Programming Languages
Results.Description: This was definitely one of my least favorite classes in the UNCW comp sci curriculum. At the beginning of the class you write parts of made-up UNCW programming language called "Jiffy" using Java. After that you work with mostly SML and Prolog. I don't think there's any real reason to know these languages and found that large part of the class kind of pointless. The more useful parts of the class include learning about memory-management, compilers, and other programming language concepts. There are 3 tests throughout each worth 17% of your final grade. The tests are infamously difficult and I'd recommend studying your notes from class, slides, and homeworks. At the end there is a 20-minute long group presentation on a programming language. Most groups have 3 members and my group was assigned Kotlin. We got a 100 on the project and he basically said it was a "give me" completion grade. However, I consider us lucky as Kotlin was one of the more well-known languages he assigned. Some obscure ones I saw included Erlang, Clojure, F#, Groovy, etc. More well-known ones included C#, Kotlin, and Ruby.
Results.Tips: He sometimes asks obscure questions about stuff you only learned in class on tests, so take notes.
Results.Grading: Assignments - 39%, Programming Language Presentation - 10%, Test 1 - 17%, Test 2 - 17%, Final Exam - 17%

Results.Name: CSC 450: Software Engineering
Results.Title: Software Engineering
Results.Description: This class is pretty straight forward. You're basically assigned to a group of 5 people at the beginning and work on a software engineering project the entire time. The project must have a backend and frontend. There are like 3 quizzes you take online at home. The rest of the grade is just milestones and attendance. Milestones are basically progress points in the project. At the end you have a 20 minute presentation. Note that for the presentation not everyone has to speak.
Results.Skills: Whatever tech-stack your team decides to use.
Results.Tips: I'd recommend using the following tech stack: Vue.js (Composition Api/Script Setup), python and flask for the backend. It's just the most beginner friendly and easiest to work with for a small project. Also definitely take advantage of the extra credit opportunities.
Results.Grading: Attendance and Completing Peer Evaluations - 30%, Term Project Deliverables (Milestones/Presentation) - 55%, Quizzes - 15% (Like 3 quizzes)

Results.Name: CSC 455: Database Design and Implementation
Results.Title: Database Design and Implementation
Results.Note: This class in now called "CSC 355". Which I think is appropriate. It's an easy class and I thinks it's good preparation CSC 450.
Results.Description: Overall I liked this class. I've always been curious about how database work and how SQL is tied into their functionality. The first part of this class is just like databases graphs and showing how the keys are connected to each other or whatever. The second part is SQL and writing queries for a database. The last part is php and a group project. I enjoyed the group project and you don't present it. You don't present it because everyone basically does the same thing. Also, the labs you do throughout are completion grades and the Final Exam is the same format as the first two tests.
Results.Grading: Labs - 20% (lowest two dropped), Quizzes and homework - 20%, Group project - 24%, Test 1 - 12%, Test 2 - 12%, Final Exam - 12%

Results.Name: ANT 207: Archaeology
Results.Title: Archaeology
Results.Description: This class had more work than I thought there would be. It's very easy though and not that bad. You basically have a 1-page double spaced writing assignment a week and sometimes a CTE. A CTE is a discussion forum post where you make your initial post, than respond to two people. The final observation project seriously isn't that bad. It's just a 2-3 page, 1.5 spaced, 12 font essay observing some human behavior on Television,Youtube, Facetime a friend, etc.
Results.Grading: CTE's - 140 (~18.7%, 7 total assignments), Assignments - 300 (40%, 10 total assignments), Quizzes - 150 (20%, 10 total assignments), Final Observation Project - 160 (~21.3%), NOTE: Theres a total of 750 points.

Results.Explanation: I don't recommend skipping CSC 131, even though you'vd definitely already taken it. Ap Comp Sci principles definitely isn't a good replacement for that class. Despite getting credit I still took CSC 131. It's essential if you don't know python programming.

Results.Description: Overall I remember this being a pretty easy class. It's like fun easy puzzles. 2 tests, a final exam, and like 10 short easy homeworks. Take notes during class and study the homework and the tests should be easy.
Results.Skills: A very small amount of Python

Results.Grading: Homework - 10%, Quizzes - 15%, 3 Tests - 60%, Final Exam - 15%

Results.Name: CSC 231: Introduction to Data Structures
Results.Title: Introduction to Data Structures
Results.Description: You learn about important data structures such as stacks, queues, linked-lists, binary search trees, etc. You also learn about algorithms like Binary Search, Merge sort, etc. and their time complexities. The tests are easy as long as you study, the labs are typically a bit more difficult.
Results.Tips: Learn how to use debug mode in PyCharm. It can very helpful when debugging data structures.
Results.Grading: Quizzes - 15%, Labs - 10% (Like 10 labs), Take Home Programming Assignments - 15% (Like 3 assignments), Test 1 - 20%, Test 2 - 20%, Final Exam - 20%

Results.Name: CSC 242: Computer Organization
Results.Title: Computer Organization
Results.Description: This was definitely one of my least favorite classes taken at UNCW. It's like converting hexadecimal and binary numbers in the beginning and then assembly code. Like 10 homeworks, 3 exams, and a final exam. She replaced our lowest test grade with the final exam grade. The final exam is pulled straight from the homework. For the tests study the homework and know how everything works.
Results.Grading: NOTE: I couldn't find the syllabus. This is from memory., 3 tests, Like 8 homeworks, Final Exam

Results.Description: Obviously don't take physics if you don't have to. Dr. Daniels is cool though.

Results.Name: Dr. Yang Song
Results.Description: I really like Dr. Song as a person and I had a good relationship with him while I was in college. However, I found his teaching style and class excessively difficult. He talks super fast in class and a lot of material on the test isn't like what's covered in class. Also a pretty work-heavy class for an elective. However, if you really want to get into AI I wouldn't let this class stop you.

Results.Name: Dr. Sridhar Narayan
Results.Description: Dr. Narayan is kind of infamous at UNCW for his sheer cruelty. While I think the accusations are somewhat over exaggerated, I still would recommend taking another professor for this class. His tests are excessively difficult and don't really contain material that he covered in class. If you ask questions he's not super helpful and will sometimes just get angry at you. Just try and take the other professor if possible.

I've recently learned that you're a Business Administration major, not a Computer Science major. I think a computer science minor could still be very helpful and enhance your degree. Basically all modern businesses use and rely on Software, so it'd be useful to have a basic understanding of it. It can also help automate excel tasks. Learn more about the minor here. For the minor you need to take CSC 131, CSC 133, CSC 231, CSC 331, and two 3-credit hour CSC electives. These are descriptions of those classes and two possible electives.
Results.DescriptionTwo: It's probably not too late to become a computer science major with a business concentration and still graduate in 4 years. I've listed coursework below. To learn more about the degree run a "What-If" analysis in Seanet. If you're interested and have questions feel free to reach out.

Results.Name: CSC 131: Introduction to Computer Science
Results.Title: Introduction to Computer Science - Python
Results.Description: I took this class online during Covid, so it's probably changed a lot. Basic python coding questions and syntax.

Results.Name: CSC 133: Discrete Mathematical Structures
Results.Title: Discrete Mathematical Structures
Results.Description: Overall I remember this being a pretty easy class. It's like fun easy puzzles. 2 tests, a final exam, and like 10 short easy homeworks. Take notes during class and study the homework and the tests should be easy.
Results.Skills: A very small amount of Python
Results.Tips: Study the homework before tests and take good notes in class.
Results.Grading: Homework - 10%, Quizzes - 15%, 3 Tests - 60%, Final Exam - 15%

Results.Name: CSC 231: Introduction to Data Structures
Results.Title: Introduction to Data Structures
Results.Description: You learn about important data structures such as stacks, queues, linked-lists, binary search trees, etc. You also learn about algorithms like Binary Search, Merge sort, etc. and their time complexities. The tests are easy as long as you study, the labs are typically a bit more difficult.
Results.Tips: Learn how to use debug mode in PyCharm. It can very helpful when debugging data structures.
Results.Grading: Quizzes - 15%, Labs - 10% (Like 10 labs), Take Home Programming Assignments - 15% (Like 3 assignments), Test 1 - 20%, Test 2 - 20%, Final Exam - 20%

Results.Name: CSC 331: Object-Oriented Programming and Design
Results.Title: Object-Oriented Programming and Design
Results.Description: This class is easy if you have any experience whatsoever with Java. It's like CSC 131 for Java instead of python. The labs are pretty easy as well as the tests. She lets you have a cheat sheet for the tests. For one lab you work in a group of 3. At the end you work in a group of 5 for a 10-minute long project presentation. The project is a JavaFx project written using Java, JavaFx, FXML, and SceneBuilder. JavaFx is a framework for building GUI's for Java. It adds logic to your FXML code, and you can use it to build UI components programmatically in your project, I did both in ours. I personally really like the framework and the end project was definitely my favorite programming project I did for UNCW.
Results.Grading: Homework - 10%, Test 1 - 10%, Test 2 - 10%, Final Project - 10%, Labs - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Attendance - 5%

Results.Name: CSC 351: Applied Software Security
Results.Title: Applied Software Security
Results.Description: This class teaches a lot of helpful information. A lot of these topics came up in job interviews and is just helpful to know for coding. The class itself is very easy and I found it's content interesting. You do 4 easy python programming assignments throughout and a couple easy multiple-choice online quizzes. The final-exam is an online taken-home coding assessment. In class Layman, shows many real life examples of things, and demonstrates concepts using JavaScript, html, C, Python, SQL, etc. While you don't have to write in these languages (except Python) just seeing them in use would probably be helpful in learning the basics of them. Overall an extremely easy class without that much work. Would highly recommend.
Results.Tips: Dr. Layman offers very generous extra credit, take advantage of it.
Results.Grading: Assignments - 40% (4 coding assignments), Quizzes - 45% (7 total), Final Exam - 15%

Results.Name: CSC 498: Internship in Computer Science
Results.Title: Internship in Computer Science
Results.Description: This is a 3 credit hour class that's pass/fail. All you do is write 1 paragraph a week summarizing what you did at your internship and at the end you create a poster presentation demonstrating what you did during your internship. Note that you don't present the poster in-front of a group. You just hang it up in Congdon Hall and stand by it the entire time. I only had like 2 people come up to ask me about it during the 2-hour showcase. Also, it's just a completion grade, so it's pretty low-stress. The computing showcase is a great place to meet and talk to employers in the Wilmington area. This was my poster. I got a 100 on it.
Results.Tips: You can't sign up for this class via Seanet. Contact Shauna White (turners@uncw.edu) if you're interested.
Results.Grading: Weekly Paragraphs - 50%, Poster presentation - 50%

Results.Name: Junior Year - 1st Semester
Results.Classes: CSC 131: Introduction to Computer Science, CSC 133: Discrete Mathematical Structures

Results.Name: Junior Year - 2nd Semester
Results.Classes: CSC 231: Introduction to Computer Science, CSC 242: Computer Organization, CSC 498: Internship in Computer Science/CSC Elective, CSC 344: Computer Networks

Results.Name: Senior Year - 1st Semester
Results.Classes: CSC 331: Object-Oriented Programming and Design, CSC 340: Scientific Computing, CSC 342: Operating Systems, CSC 385: Professional and Ethical Issues in Computing, CSC 355: Database Design and Implementation, CSC 360: Formal Languages and Computability

Results.Name: Senior Year - 2nd Semester
Results.Classes: CSC 380: Design and Analysis of Algorithms, CSC 351: Applied Software Security, CSC 434: Programming Languages, CSC 450: Software Engineering, Another CSC Elective?

Results.desc1: These are certifications that I think would be useful to get for various reasons. They would help to build your resume and teach you about important and useful skills in "real-world" software engineering. While I've never attained any of these certifications myself, I still think they could be very useful and teach you good information.
Results.desc2: Cloud computing is a very popular, widely-used tool in software engineering these days. I think these certifications would greatly help you in basically any SWE job you get.
Results.desc3: These are certifications for very commonly used skills in software engineering jobs. I've been asked about my knowledge on these skills in basically every SWE interview I've done so far.
Results.desc4: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning are all the rage these days so I thought I'd add a section on it. I also feel like UNCW's AI concentration isn't the best way to learn real-world application of these skills and that a certification might be easier and more useful to get.
Results.desc5: These are certifications and degrees from Universities that you might find helpful. I think having some form of education from another University can make up for the lack of "prestige" UNCW has.
Results.desc6: These are general tips I have a for attaining certifications to make the most out of the experience and get the most value out of the certification itself. These tips might also make the process easier.

Results.Name: Amazon Web Services
Results.Cost: $100 to take the test, free retake/preparation

Results.Name: IBM Cloud
Results.Cost: Free to take the course. No final exam.

Results.Name: Kubernetes and Docker
Results.Description: This is a course, not a certification. However, you can still definitely put your completion of it on your resume.
Results.Certification: Docker and Kubernetes: The Complete Guide

Results.Name: GitHub and Git
Results.Description: The only class at UNCW where we used GitHub was CSC 450. I think it would be very useful to learn about it beforehand as it's a MANDATORY skill to have as a software engineer. A certification will help show you actually know what you're doing and teach you important skills as well. I think using Git and GitHub for a personal project would also be a great way to learn it.

Results.Name: JUnit and Mockito
Results.Description: UNCW doesn't really teach software testing. While you may not need to know these two specific frameworks for your job, they are commonly used and will help you learn the basics. Testing is also commonly asked about in interviews. Also note that this is a course, not a certification. However, you can still definitely put your completion of it on your resume.

Results.Name: Google UX Design
Results.Description: This is Google's UX design certificate. If you had any interest in front-end development, this would probably be helpful.

Results.Name: UNC Web Developer Boot Camp
Results.Cost: They don't say. They just say "Financial options are available. Contact us to discuss your options."

Results.Name: Online Georgia Tech Masters Degree
Results.Description: I saw a guy who went to UNCW on LinkedIn get this degree. He said he had a 2.8 gpa so I don't think it's too difficult to get into.
Results.Cost: $5400 total ($180 per credit hour. 30 credit hours)

Results.Name: Stanford AI Program
Results.Cost: $1,750 per course. 8 courses to choose from.

Results.Name: Get Certifications from a Company You Want to Work At
Results.Description: If you want to work at Cisco, IBM, etc. get certifications from those companies to show commitment.

Results.Name: Some of These Courses Might Be Free at Your Job
Results.Description: I'm aware some of these certifications are pricey, but some of them might be free at your job. Like IBM offers a ton of free training courses, and USAA offered free Udemy courses.

Results.Name: Focus on One Certification at a Time
Results.Description: If you decide to get more than one of these certifications, try to focus on one at a time and actually follow through with it.

Results.Name: A Job Might Be Worth as Much as a Master's Degree
Results.Description: As you can tell some of these degrees and certifications are pricey. I feel like getting a job at a company can be worth just as much as a masters degree and you'll be getting paid instead of loosing money. I also think real-world experience with these skills can be just as valuable, if not more valuable than these certifications.

Results.Name: Get an AWS Certification
Results.Description: If you do get any of these certifications, I recommend the AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner one. While I don't have it myself, it's reasonably priced, seems to teach good information, and is a sought after skill in the job market.

Results.Body: Visual Studio Code is the text editor I use for basically all my projects. It's very popular and I've used it for all my jobs and in many college classes. It's very versatile and can be used for (basically) any programming language. It has a lot of useful extensions and has a really good git version control system. I'd strongly recommend downloading VSCode and learning the basics of it. I've provided links below to help you setup and learn how to use it. If you have any questions hmu.

Results.title: GitHub

Results.title: What is GitHub and Git?
Results.desc: GitHub is a website that uses git to help with collaboration and version control of coding projects. In simple terms, it's a place to upload your code and modify it in a controlled way. Git is version control system that allows you to add, revert, commit, push, etc. code to your repository.

Results.instruction: If you have any issues with anything definitely feel free to contact me. Note that some of these commands will be different if you're using windows.

To get started, download git. I'd recommend installing git using Homebrew. Install the Homebrew package manager using the following two commands. Then check that it's installed by using the --version command.
Now install git via Homebrew. Note that this might take a while. Be patient.

Configure Git. Replace the values in quotations with your name and email address. I'd recommend using the same email address you used to setup your Github account. I'd recommend just setting your username to "John Doe" (Your name).

Results.CopyCode:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "youremail@example.com"

Results.instruction: Now generate a new SSH key. Run the following command in your terminal with the same email you used in the previous step. Replace youremail@example.com with your actual email address.
It will then ask you questions and prompt you for answers. Just press return/enter for all of them. Different for multiple accounts.
Run the following two commands (one at a  time) to add the SSH key to the ssh-agent. Different for multiple accounts.
Run the following to ensure you have git installed. If it says something like "git version 2.39.3", you're good.
9. Now we're going to create an SSH key to add to GitHub. Run the two following commands. The second command will print and copy the ssh key to your clipboard. Different for multiple accounts.
Your SSH key should now be copied to your keyboard. Now go back to your Github account at github.com.
On GitHub, in the top-right corner click on the circular profile picture. A sidebar should appear.
In the sidebar click "settings".
You should now be taken to a new page. On the left-hand side click "SSH and GPG" keys.
Click the green "New SSH key" button. Create a title for the key, it doesn't have to be anything special. You could just call it "John's key" (your name key).
Paste the SSH key in the box. It should already be copied to your clipboard.
Click "Add SSH key" at the bottom. It should then take you back to the old page with a light blue bar that says "You have successfully added the key 'John's Key'".

Now generate a person access token by going to this GitHub link. To get this page manually you would go to the GitHub main page -> side bar -> settings -> (Scroll down left-hand side) Developer settings -> Personal access tokens.
Click the gray "Generate new token" drop-down button. In the drop-down menu select "Generate new token (classic)".

You'll be taken to a new page with multiple fields titled "New personal access token (classic)". In the "Note" field just type something like "John's Personal Access Token". Then select 90 days for the expiration. Then check ALL the boxes below. Then select the green "Generate token" button at the bottom once you're done.
A new personal access token should have been generated. Copy it, and keep it somewhere safe. You will NOT be able to see it again. It should look like ghp_followed by a bunch random characters.
Add a nano config file by running the following command.
Now run the following command to open your nano file. This is where you'll add your personal access token information.

In the file that's open in your terminal paste the following. Note change "NameForThisAccount" in the first line with basically any name for this new account. I'd recommend something like "main" or "personal". Different for multiple accounts.

Results.CopyCode:
# Main account
Host github.com-NameForThisAccount
HostName github.com
User git
IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
IdentitiesOnly yes

Results.instruction: To save the file do the following. Press control + o. Then press return/enter. Then press control + x.
Run the following command again to verify the changes were saved. Then press control + x to exit.
Go to github.com.
On the left-hand side click the green "New" button.
In the "Repository name *" field enter a name for your repository. It can be basically anything.
Decide if you want to make the repo "private" or "public". Select the corresponding radio button. I'd recommend "public" for this example.
I'd recommend checking the "Add a README file" button.
Select the green "Create repository" button at the bottom.

In the light blue section titled "Quick setup ‚Äî if you've done this kind of thing before". Select https or ssh, either one works but I"d recommend selecting ssh. Then copy the link next to it that looks like "git@github.com:Michael-W23/Wind.git" if you selected ssh. Different for multiple accounts.

Run the following command to create a local clone. Note the link should be whatever you just copied. Replace the "git@github.com:John-Smith/PacMan.git" with the actual link. Different for multiple accounts
Change into the cloned repository. Using the "cd" command. Note you should cd into whatever the repos name is. Different for multiple accounts
Add files and make your changes. You can just run the following command for this example.
Add all your changes.
Commit your changes with a message about your changes in quotations.
Push your changes.
Go back to your repository on GitHub and you should see that the "test.py" file has been added.
Note that commands 11-13 are how you will add, commit, and push all your future changes.

After you enter the command from step 5 you'll be asked the following question, "Enter file in which to save the key (/Users/johndoe/.ssh/id_ed25519):". Write the name of the file where you want to save the new SSH key without an extension.  For this example lets call it "id_ed25519_two", then press return/enter. Scroll back up to original step.

This is basically but the same as the regular step 7, but with a changed file name. Run the following two commands (one at a  time) to add the SSH key to the ssh-agent. Again, note the file name is different ("id_ed25519_two"). Scroll back up to original step.

This is basically but the same as the regular step 9, but with a changed file name. Run the following two commands (one at a  time) to copy the ssh key to your clipboard. The second command will print and copy the ssh key to your clipboard. Again, note the file name is different ("id_ed25519_two"). Scroll back up to original step.
This is basically the same as regular step 23. Change "NameForThisAccount" to something other than your other account's name. Also the IdentityFile has been updated. Scroll back up to original step.

Results.CopyCode:
# Main account
Host github.com-NameForThisAccount
HostName github.com
User git
IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_two
IdentitiesOnly yes

Results.instruction: In the light blue section titled "Quick setup ‚Äî if you've done this kind of thing before". Select the "ssh" button. Note that you HAVE to select "ssh" for this to work with a second account. Then copy the link next to it that looks like "git clone git@github.com:John-Smith/PacMan.git". Scroll back up to original step.

Open your ~/.ssh/config file using the following command. Copy and record the "-NameForThisAccount". It should look something like "Host github.com-NameForThisAccount" in the file. You'll need it for step 9. Scroll back up to original step.

Change into the repository and then set the user email to the email of your second github account. Also set the username to the username of your second account.Your commits will probably be linked to your main account if you don't do this.<br><br>If you can't find you're email go to github.com. Click on your profile picture in the top-left then click "Settings" in the menu. Then on the left-hand side look for "Emails". Click on it and you should see your accounts email address.<br><br>Note that when you add the remote origin it should use the SSH link from GitHub, not the HTTPS link. You should also add "-NameForThisAccount" after the "github.com" part of the link. Make sure to configure your email and username before adding the remote origin. I showed this in the commands below. <br><br> When you're done you can Scroll back up to original step.

Results.CopyCode:
mkdir PacMan
cd PacMan

git init
git config user.email "your-second-accounts-email"
git config user.name "your-second-accounts-username"

git add .
git commit -m "Initial Commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin git@github.com-NameForThisAccount:John-Smith/PacMan.git
git push -u origin main

Results.instruction: Create a feature branch when you start work on a new user story or feature.

Fetch all changes from the remote main branch and merge them into your local copy.
Create a feature branch off the main branch. Replace "my_feature" with a name related to the user story.
Share your feature branch to the remote (GitHub).

Change into your branch, pull changes, then start writing you code.

Results.Description: Ensure you are in your feature branch.
Ensure that you have the latest changes from the remote. If there are any merge conflicts resolve them before continuing.

Before running these commands, ensure that your project builds without errors.

Stage all your working directory changes to be saved.

Results.Command: git commit -m "A concise description of changes"
Results.Description: Create a new version of your feature branch.
Share your new commits to the remote. You can add and commit multiple versions before pushing.

Results.instruction: The following steps explain how to merge a branch into main when you're ready.
Before doing any of this make sure the changes from your branch are committed. Running the "git status" command should output "nothing to commit, working tree clean".

Results.Description: Check that you're on your branch and that all changed files have been committed.
Switch to the main branch.
Ensure that your local main is up to date with the remote. Resolve any merge conflicts before continuing.
Switch back to your my_feature branch
Merge the changes from the main branch into the my_feature branch. This ensures that your feature incorporates new versions of main. Resolve any merge conflicts before continuing.
Stage all changes you have made to resolve the merge. (This step may not be necessary and will have no effect)

Results.Command: git commit -m "A concise description of changes"
Results.Description: Create a new version of your feature branch.
Send the merged version of your feature branch to the remote.

Results.instruction: Go to the Github repository you just pushed changes to. At the top you should see a green "Compare & pull request" button next to "your-branch-name" had recent changes. Click on the button. On the new page make sure the "compare" drop down menu has your branch name next to it. Then in the "Add a description" text-box write a description of all the changes you made in your branch. Then click the "Create pull request" button.
Do NOT push the green "Pull merge request" button. Instead, copy the link to your pull request and send it to your dev lead. Ask them to review the PR and merge it into main if it looks good.
If your reviewer requests changes, go into your feature branch, make code changes, add, commit, and push to update.

Results.instruction: Go to GitHub, go to the Amotions repo, click "branches", and click "create a pull request" on the branch.

Select "dev" for the base branch in the top left corner, write a comment about your pull request, then click the green "Create pull request" button. If you click the "Create pull request" button before you select the "dev" base branch, just follow the steps in this page to refactor -> Link.

On GitHub a bot will generate a netlify bot will generate a preview link, next to the text that says Deploy Preview. Wait like 5 minutes for all changes to be made, then click on the link to see changes.
Go to "Slack" and in the "#engineering" section ask someone to review and test the pull request before merging. In your post include the Github PR link and the preview link.
Once your changes are approved click the green "Merge pull request" button. Then click "Confirm merge". Do not delete the branch yet.
Go to the "code tab", than go back to the "pull request" tab and click the green "New pull request" button (On the right, near the top). You're going to merge your branch with main now.
Select the branch you want to merge in the "compare:" drop down. Base should be main. Click the green "Create pull request" button (On the right, near the top).
Write your commit message then click the green "Create pull request" button.
Wait for the automatic tests to finish, then click the green "Merge pull request" button. Then click "Confirm merge".
Wait like 5 minutes, check that it's working of the production website, then report on Slack in "#general".
Delete your branch

Results.instruction: Install homebrew. Homebrew is a great package manager for git and other software.
Include a ReadMe. ReadMes are a great way to add a description about your project as well as other information.

Don't edit ReadMes on GitHub do it in a local repo/md file. Editing ReadMe's on git can cause your local and remote repository changes to be out of sync. If you do make changes on GitHub do a "git pull" before editing locally. If you already made changes locally use the following commands to pull your ReadMe changes.

Results.CopyCode:
git fetch origin
git commit -m "Pulled changes"

Results.instruction: If you want to remove git from a folder/directory use the following command.
Learn markdown. Markdown is how you add styling to ReadMe's. You can also use HTML to style an md file. This website is a good source to learn markdown.
Pull remote changes to your local repo before you start working. It's usually a good idea to pull changes from the same branch into your local repo before you start making changes.

Check issues GitHub. If you see something wrong with a repo, check the "issues" tab. Someone before you might have asked about the issue and got a response. You can also open an issue if you want to add something or you're having trouble with something.
Store personal access tokens somewhere safe. You only see your personal access token, once when it's first generated. Store it somewhere safe in case you need it again.
Make git commit messages short. They don't have to be long. Give a very brief overview of the problem, so it doesn't run off screen. A person at IBM gave me this advice.

Results.Description: Stage all changes
Stage all changes. Add a commit message.
Results.Example: git commit -m "Added search functionality to Home page"

See what branch you're currently on
Create a new branch and switch to it immediately
create a new branch without switching to it

Pushes the local branch's commits to a remote branch on the origin. Do once when pushing a new branch.
Takes all staged and unstaged changes and saves them for later. Then reverts your working directory to the last commit state.
Show differences between commits, branches, files, etc.
