Results.instruction: Go to the Github repository you want to fork.
Click the "fork" button on the right-hand side.
In the drop down click "Create a new fork".
You should be taken to a new page. Change the name/description if you want. Then click the green "Create fork" button.
There should now be a fork on your GitHub page.

To make changes locally clone the repo. First go the green "Code" button, in the drop down select the "SSH" tab and copy the url. Then clone it using the following command. Change the SSH link in the command to be the actual forked repo link. Make sure to add the "-NameForThisAccount" after the github.com if you're using a Github account other than your main one.
Change into the local repo using the cd command. Replace with the actual name of the repo.
Make changes to your local repository that you want to add.
Run the following three commands like any other project to push your changes.

Results.desc: These are UI/UX Design Tips.

Results.Underlined: Have a "Center" of the page that contains all necessary components and information
Results.Tip: The sides could contain components that disappear when the screen shrinks to a different width. You could also change the components being displayed and have a component with identical functionality.

Results.Underlined: Think of your UI as a vertical stack
Results.Tip: Code and design your UI starting from the top to bottom. Add side components after you design the center. Not that a "div" element in HTML vertically stacks elements on the page. Think about components like stacking bricks on top of each other.

Results.Underlined: Use padding and relative positioning instead of absolute positioning
Results.Tip: This will help your UI components collapse and expand synchronously with different screen sizes.

Results.Underlined: Use fonts, logos, and colors to make your UI look unique, not designs
Results.Tip: Many UI designs and components are very similar, but you probably haven't really noticed due to the different fonts, logos, and colors. For example, the YouTube subscription page and the instagram main scroll page and basically the exact same, but look completely different due to their different fonts, colors, and overall "vibe". Try not to make excessively weird/confusing UI designs. Try for the for the most part to use vertically stacked rectangles, squares, and circles were appropriate.

Whenever the user hovers over something or clicks something, have the UI respond to it in someway. For example, when the user hovers over a button, change its color or make it bigger to indicate that it does something when clicked. Whenever a button is clicked always indicate through either button text changes, color changes, alerts, etc. whether the action was performed successfully or not.

Most popular UI's such as YouTube, TikTok, Instagram, etc. use mostly muted colors such as grey, white, and black with a small "splash" of colors like blue, red, purple, etc. A completely bright neon red UI probably won't look good, and a completely grey UI might come across as dull or bland. Try to find a good mixture of both, I'd say like 85-90% muted, and 10% colorful. Also try to spread the color throughout the UI and not have it all be in one place.
Kind of elaborating on point 4, be observant when you're using apps and look out for UI designs you like and try to take inspiration from them.

Results.Underlined: Collapse horizontally stacked elements into vertically stacked elements when the screen's width decreases
Results.Tip: For example, say you have a row of horizontally aligned cards. When the user shrinks the width of the screen the cards could go underneath one another in a vertical stack.

What I mean by "whitespace" in this context is part of the screen that contains just color and no UI components. The main benefit of this is that will help your design adapt to different screen sizes better. Since the size of the colored background isn't essential it can expand and shrink as necessary. It also helps keep your UI look "Clean" and not overly cluttered.

Results.Underlined: For mobile development, use cards that take up the entire width of the screen
Results.Tip: A common UI design for apps is to make white cards that take the entire width of the screen. These cards could contain information and components like buttons.
Try to make a somewhat simple, easy to understand user interface. Make buttons that perform intuitive actions, place views in places that makes sense, create obvious navigation, etc.

What I mean by this is don't use icons and buttons that perform non-intuitive actions. An example of this would be a search magnifying glass icon that leads into a different screen where you select items. That's not what you'd expect that icon to do when clicked.
Drawing designs on paper is a great way to save time and plan what you're going to do.
Make sure you app has easy, intuitive ways to undo an action. An example of this would be the ability to unsend or edit a text in a messaging app.

Results.Underlined: Read "8 Golden Rules of Interface Design" by Ben Schneiderman
Results.Tip: This is a relatively short article that Dr. Layman shared with us in CSC 450. It has some really good advice and you can check it out here.

Title: Deploy a Vanilla JS Project to GitHub Pages üìú

Results.title: Deploy a Vanilla JS Project to GitHub Pages
Results.desc: How to deploy a project that doesn't use Vite or a JS framework to GitHub pages. This is a good reference video.

Results.instruction: Write your non-vite html, css, and javascript code, then push it to github. Make sure there's a file named "index.html" in the top-most directory of your folder.
When you're ready to deploy do the following steps.
Go to your repository. In the top-right click on "Settings" with the gear icon next to it.
On the left-hand side under "Code and automation" select "Pages".

Under "Build and Deployment" you should see a section titled "Branch". Under it select the "None" button and decide what branch you want to deploy. You likely want to deploy the "main" branch. You also likely don't want to change the "(root)" button.
Once done, press "Save".
Wait about 1-2 minutes, then refresh the page. You should now see the link to your GitHub pages website.

Title: Deploy a Vite Project to GitHub Pages ‚ö°Ô∏è

Results.title: Deploy a Vite Project to GitHub Pages
Results.desc: How to deploy a project that uses Vite and a JS framework to GitHub pages (Vue, React, Etc.). This is a good reference video.

Results.instruction: Ensure that the code for your app is already on GitHub and that you have a local git repository set up for your code. Change into your local folder and run the following "git status" command. If it doesn't output something like "fatal: not a git repository (or any of the parent directories)" you should be good.
Change into your local Vite project repository and open it in VSCode. You can open it using the "code ." command if you have it installed.

Step 3 if you're using Vue. Open the "vite.config.js" file in your folder. Delete the contents of the folder and paste in the following code. Change the "name-of-github-repo". To the actual name of your GitHub repository. Keep the slashes before and after the name.

Step 3 if you're using React. Open the "vite.config.js" file in your folder. Delete the contents of the folder and paste in the following code. Change the "name-of-github-repo". To the actual name of your GitHub repository. Keep the slashes before and after the name.

Step 4 if you're using Vue router, go to your index.js file in the src/router directory. Where it says "history: createWebHistory('/')". Change the createWebHistory parameter to be the name of your GitHub repository starting and ending with slashes. If you're not using Vue-router you can skip this step.

Step 4 if you're using React router. Go to your index.js file in the src/router directory. Where it says "Router" change it to include a "basename" prop and set its value to be the name of your GitHub repository. It should start with a slash. You only need to change that one line. If you're not using React router you can skip this step.
Run the following commands in your terminal. Make sure you're still in your local repository using "pwd".

Results.CopyCode:
pwd
npm run build
cp dist/index.html dist/404.html
git add dist -f
git commit -m "Adding dist"
git subtree push --prefix dist origin gh-pages

Results.instruction: Now go to your Github repository, You should see that a new branch named "gh-pages" has been added. Now can click on the "main" drop-down button right above the code to see your branches.
Click on the "Settings" tab in the top-bar near the right-hand side. It has a gear icon next to it.

Now in the "Code and automation" section on the left-hand side click on "Pages" and wait while it deploys to Github pages. You should eventually see a link there where you can access your site. You should be done now. The following steps are to make changes to your deployed site.

To update the site while working on the main branch run the following commands. These will update both the main branch and gh-pages branch. You could make a python script that uses the "os" library to automate this process.

Results.CopyCode:
git add .
git commit -m "Message"
git push origin main
npm run build
cp dist/index.html dist/404.html
git add dist -f
git commit -m "Message"
git subtree push --prefix dist origin gh-pages

Results.instruction: If the subtree push doesn't work for some reason try the following.

Results.CopyCode: git push origin `git subtree --split prefix dist main`:gh-pages --force

Results.instruction: If you're getting errors on your deployed site make sure you're not using anchor tags for router links.
I've included an automation script in the section below you can use to update your Github pages website.

Results.title: Automate Vite Github Pages Update
Results.desc: Explains how to automate uploading changes to Github pages using Python.

Results.instruction: Run the following commands in your terminal.

Results.CopyCode:
pip3 install termcolor
cd your-project-name
touch update_github_pages.py

Results.instruction: Open the update_github_pages.py file in VSCode and paste in the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
import os
import subprocess
from termcolor import colored as c

process = subprocess.run('git status', shell=True, capture_output=True, text=True)

output = process.stdout

branch = repr(output).split"\\n".replace("'On branch ", "").strip()

print('On branch ', end="")

if branch == 'main':
	print(c(branch, 'green'))
else:
	print(c(branch, 'red'))
	print('Move changes to the main branch, then switch to the main branch.')
	print('git stash')
	print('git checkout main')
	print('git pull origin main')
	print(f'git merge {branch}')
	print('git stash apply')
	print('git push origin main')
	exit(0)

commit_msg = input("Enter your commit message: ")

os.system('git add .')
os.system(f'git commit -m "{commit_msg}"')
os.system('git push origin main')
os.system('npm run build')
os.system('cp dist/index.html dist/404.html')
os.system('git add dist -f')
os.system(f'git commit -m "{commit_msg}"')
os.system('git subtree push --prefix dist origin gh-pages')

from flask import Flask
from db import init_db
from routes import routes_blueprint
from flask_cors import CORS
from config import Config

def create_app():
	app = Flask(__name__)
	app.config.from_object(Config)

	CORS(app, resources={r'/*': {'origins': '*'}})
	init_db(app)

	app.register_blueprint(routes_blueprint)
	return app

if __name__ == '__main__':
	app = create_app()
	app.run(debug=True)

Results.title: Technologies We'll Use

Results.instruction: <u><b>Vue</u></b> - The JavaScript Framework we'll use to build our user interface.
<u><b>JavaScript</u></b> - The scripting language we'll use to add logic to our frontend.
<u><b>Flask</u></b> - The Python web framework we'll use to help build our Rest Api.
<u><b>Python</u></b> - The programming language we'll use to develop our Rest Api.
<u><b>SQL</u></b> - The language we'll use to help build and query our database.
<u><b>PostgreSQL</u></b> - The database we'll use to store user information.
<u><b>Visual Studio Code</u></b> - The code editor we'll use to help us build our project.
<u><b>PyTest</u></b> - The Python testing framework we'll use to test our Rest Api.
<u><b>Jest</u></b> - The JavaScript testing framework we'll use to test our Vue code.
<u><b>Github</u></b> - The platform we'll use for version control and collaborative software development.
<u><b>Git</u></b> - The distributed version control system we'll use to track changes to our projects.
<u><b>Homebrew</u></b> - MacOS package manager we'll use to install software. Optional to use.

Results.title: Flask Rest API Folder Setup Explanation
Results.desc: Explains the purpose of the various folders and what code they should contain.

Results.instruction: <u><b>api/errors</u></b> - Where the custom exceptions for your project will be kept.
<u><b>api/models</u></b> - Python classes that represent the objects in your database.

<u><b>api/repositories</u></b> - All functions that will be used to query and "talk to" your database. These should just be your simple sql queries. Your business logic will be applied in the "services" folder.

<u><b>api/routes</u></b> - Where your endpoints will be stored. All data returned from this Rest API will happen in this folder. The logic and functions you use to "talk to" your database should be in your "services" and "repositories" folder. Keep your endpoint functions short and clean.

<u><b>api/schemas</u></b> - Serializes and deserializes JSON data using the python "Marshmellow" library. Basically it will take a JSON object response and convert it into a Python model object. It will also do the opposite and convert a Python model object into a JSON object.
<u><b>api/services</u></b> - Functions that use your repository functions to create business logic in your application.
<u><b>api/utils</u></b> - Common functions that are reused in various parts of your Rest API.
<u><b>tests/db_testing</u></b> - Where you'll test your database connection.
<u><b>tests/endpoint_testing</u></b> - Test your endpoints.
<u><b>tests/services_testing</u></b> - Test your service functions.

import os
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS
from api.routes.endpoints import routes_blueprint
from db import db, init_app

def create_app(config=None):
    app = Flask(__name__)

    if config is None:
        config = os.getenv("FLASK_ENV")

    if config == "development":
        app.config.from_object("config.DevelopmentConfig")
    elif config == "testing":
        app.config.from_object("config.TestingConfig")
    else:
        app.config.from_object("config.ProductionConfig")

    CORS(app, resources={r'/*': {'origins': '*'}})

    db.init_app(app)

    app.register_blueprint(routes_blueprint)
    return app


if __name__ == '__main__':
    app = create_app()
    app.run()

Results.CopyCode:
from sqlalchemy import Column, ForeignKey, func
from sqlalchemy.orm import relationship, Mapped, mapped_column
from datetime import datetime
from db import db

# Association table for the many-to-many relationship between Notes and Tags
note_tags_association_table = db.Table(
    'note_tags', db.Model.metadata,
    Column('note_id', db.Integer, ForeignKey('notes.note_id', ondelete='CASCADE'), primary_key=True),
    Column('tag_id', db.Integer, ForeignKey('tags.tag_id', ondelete='CASCADE'), primary_key=True)
)


class User(db.Model):
    """
    User model for the database interactions.
    """
    __tablename__ = 'users'

    user_id: Mapped[int] = mapped_column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    username: Mapped[str] = mapped_column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    email: Mapped[str] = mapped_column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password_hash: Mapped[str] = mapped_column(db.String(255), nullable=False)
    created_at: Mapped[datetime] = mapped_column(db.DateTime, nullable=False, default=func.now())

    # One-to-many relationship with Note model
    notes = relationship('Note', back_populates='user', cascade="all, delete-orphan")

    def to_dict(self):
        """Convert the user object to a dictionary, excluding sensitive data."""
        return {
            "user_id": self.user_id,
            "username": self.username,
            "email": self.email,
            "created_at": self.created_at.isoformat()
        }


class Note(db.Model):
    """
    Note model for the database interactions.
    """
    __tablename__ = 'notes'

    note_id: Mapped[int] = mapped_column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    title: Mapped[str] = mapped_column(db.String(200))
    content: Mapped[str] = mapped_column(db.Text)
    created_at: Mapped[datetime] = mapped_column(db.DateTime, default=func.now())
    updated_at: Mapped[datetime] = mapped_column(db.DateTime, default=func.now(), onupdate=func.now())
    user_id: Mapped[int] = mapped_column(db.Integer, ForeignKey('users.user_id', ondelete='CASCADE'), nullable=False)

    # Many-to-one relationship with User model
    user = relationship('User', back_populates='notes')

    # Many-to-many relationship with Tag model using note_tags_association_table
    tags = relationship('Tag', secondary=note_tags_association_table, back_populates='notes')

    def to_dict(self):
        return {
            "note_id": self.note_id,
            "title": self.title,
            "content": self.content,
            "created_at": self.created_at.isoformat(),
            "updated_at": self.updated_at.isoformat(),
            "user_id": self.user_id,
            "tags": [tag.to_dict() for tag in self.tags]
        }


class Tag(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'tags'

    tag_id: Mapped[int] = mapped_column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name: Mapped[str] = mapped_column(db.String(50), unique=True, nullable=False)

    # Many-to-many relationship with Note model using note_tags_association_table
    notes = relationship('Note', secondary=note_tags_association_table, back_populates='tags')

    def to_dict(self):
        return {
            "tag_id": self.tag_id,
            "name": self.name,
            "notes": [note.note_id for note in self.notes]
        }

Results.title: Vue Website Folder Setup Explanation
Results.desc: Explanation of the folders that will be used for your frontend code.

Results.instruction: <u><b>src/api</u></b> - Functions used to call and interact with your backend Rest API endpoints. It's a similar concept to the repository functions interacting with the database.
<u><b>src/assets</u></b> - Where you'll put things like your pictures,
<u><b>src/components</u></b> - Components that you can use in your views. An example would a Note card.
<u><b>src/lib</u></b> - Where you'll put the link to where your backend Rest API is being hosted. For this project it should probably be something like "http://127.0.0.1:5000" in Development.
<u><b>src/router</u></b> - The paths of your application. Used to navigate between pages in your application.
<u><b>src/services</u></b> - Business logic for your api functions.
<u><b>src/stores</u></b> - A management system you can use to store data and methods you can use to modify and interact with it. It's pretty similar to a class.
<u><b>src/utils</u></b> - Common functions that are used across various views.
<u><b>src/views</u></b> - The pages of your application. The components will be used in these views.
<u><b>public</u></b> - Where to store things like videos and files that the user can download

Title: Deploy the Vue, Flask and PostgreSQL app to Amazon Web Services üöÄ

Results.title: Deploy the Vue, Flask and PostgreSQL app to Amazon Web Services
Results.desc: Explains how to deploy the Notes app using various AWS services.

Results.instruction: Before doing any of this make sure you've completed the &How to Setup an Amazon Web Services Account&[AWSLink] instruction set.
Before doing any of this make sure you've completed the &How to Setup an Amazon Web Services Account&[AWSLink] instruction set.
You'll also need to complete the &How to Make a Complex Rest API using Vue, Flask and PostgreSQL&[FlaskPostLink] instruction set.
After you've completed those two instruction sets, you'll be ready to start this one.
Let's get started!

Results.title: Services We'll Use
Results.desc: These are the AWS services and technologies we'll use to deploy our app.

Results.instruction: <u><b>RDS</b></u> - How we'll deploy our Postgres database. Stands for Relational Database Service. The service can be used to set up, operate, and scale relational databases in the cloud.
<u><b>Lambda</b></u> - How we'll deploy our Rest API. It allows you to execute your code in response to specific events or triggers.
<u><b>API Gateway</b></u> - How we'll create a link that be can used in the frontend to communicate with our backend on Lambda.
<u><b>S3</b></u> - Where we'll store our Flask rest api code and frontend code. It will be used to create the http link for our application. S3 stands for simple storage service.
<u><b>CloudFront</b></u> - How we'll create the HTTPS link for our website. CloudFront is a content delivery network.
<u><b>sqlectron</b></u> - This isn't an AWS service, it's a tool we'll use to connect and work with our database.
<u><b>Zappa</b></u> - A python library we'll use to help deploy our Flask app to AWS lambda. It makes deploying the Flask code very simple, fast and easy.

Results.title: Download sqlectron
Results.desc: Explains how to download and setup sqlectron before doing anything else.

Results.instruction: Go here to install it. Press the "Download GUI" button. You'll be taken to Github.
On Github scroll down to "Assets". If you're on mac press "sqlectron-1.38.0.dmg" to install it.
Now go to "Downloads" in Finder. Press on the "sqlectron-1.38.0.dmg" file. Then drag the icon to the "Applications" folder.
Now in Finder go to "Applications". Find "sqlectron" and press on it. When asked "Are you sure you want to open it" press the "Open" button.
If it opens successfully you should be good.

Results.title: Setup the RDS DB Instance
Results.desc: Explains how to setup an RDS DB instance for PostgreSQL.

Results.instruction: Most of this information comes from this video and this video.
Go to your AWS Console. Press the "Sign In to the Console" button in the top-right.
You'll be taken to a new screen. Press the "Sign in using root user email" button. Then log in using your credentials, then press "Next".
You should now be on the "Console Home" page. Go the search bar and type "RDS" click on the result that says "RDS".
Scroll down a little to the "Create database" section. Press the orange "Create database" button.
On the "Create database" page select the following options.

Results.CopyCode:
Choose a database creation method 
 - Standard create


Engine Options 

 - Engine type: PostgreSQL 
 - Leave everything else default


Templates
  - Free tier

Settings 
  - DB instance identifier: notes-db-instance
  - Master username: create a username (remember it)
  - Credentials management: Self managed
  - Master password: Create a password (remember it)
  - Confirm master password: Same as master password


Instance configuration
  - Leave everything default
  - DB instance class: Burstable classes (includes t classes)
  - db.t3.micro


Storage 
   - Storage type: General Purpose SSD (gp2)
   - Allocated storage: 20
   - Open "Storage autoscaling" 
   - Uncheck "Enable storage autoscaling"

Connectivity
   - Leave everything default except "Public access"
   - Compute resource: Don't connect to an EC2 compute resource 
   - Virtual private cloud (VPC): Default VPC (vpc-131498791374)
   - DB subnet group: default 
   - Public access: Yes
   - VPC security group (firewall): Choose existing
   - Existing VPC security groups: default
   - Availability Zone: No preference 
   - Additional configuration: 5432


Database authentication
   - Password authentication 

Monitoring
   - Leave everything default
   - Retention period for Performance Insights: 7 days (free tier)
   - AWS KMS key: (default) aws/rds


Additional configuration
   - Initial database name: initial_db
   - DB parameter group: default.postgres16
   - Uncheck "Enable automated backups"
   - Keep "Enable encryption" checked.
   - Keep "Enable auto minor version upgrade" checked
   - Keep "Maintenance window" selected as "No preference"


Estimated Monthly costs
   - Look at the estimated monthly costs it should be around $15 dollars
   - Note it should NOT cost you nearly that much. It will probably be basically free if you don't use it.


*Do NOT Press the "Create database" button yet*

Results.instruction: Copy and record the values of "Master username" and "Master password" in settings. Also copy and record the value of "Initial database name" in the "Additional configuration" section. After you've copied the values press the "Create database" button.
If you get a pop-up saying "Suggested add-ons for notes-db-instance" look at your options, then close it.

After confirming that it works, go back to your terminal and press "control + c" to stop running your Rest api. Then deactivate it using the following command.
Open your "Notes-Rest-Api" and open the "app.py" file. Delete the "if __name__ == '__main__':" block. Replace it with just create_app. Also just the config to "production" for deployment.

Results.CopyCode:
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS
from api.routes.endpoints import routes_blueprint
from db import db, init_app

def create_app(config = "production"):
    app = Flask(__name__)

    if config == "development":
        app.config.from_object("config.DevelopmentConfig")
    elif config == "testing":
        app.config.from_object("config.TestingConfig")
    else:
        app.config.from_object("config.ProductionConfig")

    CORS(app, resources={r'/*': {'origins': '*'}})

    db.init_app(app)

    app.register_blueprint(routes_blueprint)
    return app

app = create_app()

Results.title: Delete Your AWS Services
Results.desc: Explains how to undeploy your project once you're done.

Results.instruction: I'd strongly recommend getting the AWS Console iOS app. It's great for monitoring your costs.
First we'll delete the our AWS Services, then we'll delete our local PostgreSQL database.
We'll start by deleting our RDS database instance. First go to the RDS dashboard using this link.
In the left-hand sidebar press "Database".
In the "Databases" table select the circle next to your DB identifier. Then press "Actions". In the menu press "Delete".

If you want to keep snapshot of your data keep the "Create final snapshot" box checked. If you don't uncheck it and the check the "I acknowledge" box. After that type "delete me" into the textfield. Then press "Delete".
It will probably like 5 minutes for your DB instance to be deleted. The blue loading banner at the top should green.
Now we'll delete our S3 Buckets. Make sure that your database instance was successfully deleted first though.
Go to the S3 dashboard using this link.
In the "General purpose buckets" table select the circle to the Name that contains "zappa" in it. Then press "Delete" to the left of "Create bucket".
You should be taken to a new page. Copy and paste the name of your bucket into the textfield. Then press the "Delete bucket" button.
After you do that you should see a green success message that says "Successfully deleted bucket "your-bucket-name"".
Before we can delete the bucket that contains your frontend code, we'll need to delete some of it's contents. Click on the blue name link in the table.
You should be taken to a new page with an "Objects" table. Select every file and folder in the table. Then press "Delete". You'll be taken to a new page.
Scroll down to the "Permanently delete objects?" section and type "permanently delete" in the textfield. Then press "Delete objects".

You should see a green "Successfully deleted objects" banner message. Scroll up and press the orange "Close" button in the top-right. Confirm there's nothing in the "Objects" table. The bucket hasn't been deleted yet.
Go back to the S3 console using this link.
In the "General purpose buckets" section, select the circle next to the name of your frontend code bucket. Then press "Delete".
You should be taken to a new page. Copy and paste the name of your bucket into the textfield. Then press the "Delete bucket" button.
You should now see a green banner message that says "Successfully deleted bucket "your-bucket-name"".
Congratulations! You should now have successfully deleted all your S3 buckets.
Now we'll delete our API Gateway.
Go to the API Gateway dashboard using this link.
In the "APIs" section select the circle of your api gateway in the table. Then press "Delete".
Type "confirm" when prompted and then press "Delete". You should see a green banner message that it was successfully deleted.
Now we'll delete our Lambda instance.
Go to the API Gateway dashboard using this link.
In the "Functions" section check the box next to your function name. Then press "Actions" and press "Delete" in the menu.

In the pop-up type "delete" in the textfield, then press the "Delete" button. You should see the name of your function in green if it deleted successfully. Then press "Close". You should no longer see your function in the table.
Now we'll delete our CloudFront distribution.
Go to the CloudFront dashboard using this link.
In the "Distributions" table press the box next to your distribution ID. Then press "Disable". When prompted again in the pop-up, press "Disable".

Now wait like 5 minutes for your distribution to be disabled. Then after 5 minutes, check the box next to your ID again. The "Delete" button should now be enabled, press it to delete your distribution.
If you a green banner it means you have successfully deleted your distribution.
Congratulations! You should now have successfully deleted all your AWS Services for this project.

Results.instruction: Now open a new terminal and run the following command. It will rename your project to be "spring-boot-h2". You should be in your root directory when you run this command.

Run the following commands to crate new folders/files in your project. Instead of using the "touch" commands, I'd recommend just right clicking on folders in VSCode and press "New file" for Java files. It will auto-generate packages and boiler-plate code for the file. I just included the "touch" commands because I thought they'd be convenient and I've included the necessary code below.

cd spring-boot-h2/src/main/java/com/springbackend/demo

mkdir config
mkdir controllers
mkdir models
mkdir repositories
mkdir services

touch config/WebConfig.java
touch config/H2ServerConfiguration.java
touch controllers/UserController.java
touch models/User.java
touch repositories/UserRepository.java
touch services/UserService.java

cd ~/spring-boot-h2
touch system.properties
touch .env
clear

Results.instruction: Just for future reference, you can go to Maven Central to search for new Maven dependencies or to verify that the dependencies you're using actually exist.

Now open your "spring-boot-h2" folder in VSCode. Then open "pom.xml" and paste the following data in between the <dependencies> tags. Paste the data at the end of the section, which should be around line 47. Make sure to paste it above the last </dependencies> tag. Put your cursor at the very beginning of the line, then paste the data to make it align with the other objects (it will still work if the alignment is off). Relevant Meme.

Now press "command + p". Search for and press on "application.properties". Delete the files contents and paste the following values into the file. If you can't find "application.properties" it can be found in src -> main -> resources.

spring.application.name=demo
logging.level.root=OFF
logging.level.org.springframework.boot=ERROR
logging.level.org.springframework.web=ERROR
spring.main.banner-mode=OFF
spring.datasource.driverClassName=org.h2.Driver
spring.datasource.url=${DB_URL}
spring.datasource.username=${DB_USERNAME}
spring.datasource.password=${DB_PASSWORD}
spring.jpa.database-platform=org.hibernate.dialect.H2Dialect
spring.h2.console.enabled=true
spring.jpa.show-sql=true
spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=update

Also if part of your "DB_URL" variable is grayed out it's fine.

Results.instruction: Clone my forked tiktok-downloader repository using the following command.

Results.CopyCode:
"""

This is a command line interface tool to make using
the tiktok-downloader from the link below easier and
more efficient.

https://github.com/n0l3r/tiktok-downloader

tiktok-downloader and tiktoks should be on your main
path for this to work. Ex: /Users/username/tiktoks

"""

import os
import subprocess
from termcolor import colored as c
import requests
#This command worked to install bs4 -> sudo python3 -m pip install bs4

def get_website_link(app_link: str) -> str:
	try:
		response = requests.get(app_link, allow_redirects=True)
		website_link = response.url
		return website_link
	except requests.RequestException as e:
		print(f"An error occurred: {e}")
		return None

def write_to_clipboard(output: str):
	process = subprocess.Popen('pbcopy', env={'LANG': 'en_US.UTF-8'}, stdin=subprocess.PIPE)
	process.communicate(output.encode('utf-8'))

print(c("Remember that you can NOT download slideshows", 'red'))
print(c("The website link will be fetched using the app link and copied to the clipboard.", 'blue'))

link = input("\nEnter TikTok app link: ")

if link.strip():
	website_link = get_website_link(link)

	write_to_clipboard(website_link)
	print(c("Website link copied to clipboard", 'green'), end="")
	print(f": {website_link}")
	#webbrowser.open(link.strip())

os.chdir("../tiktok-downloader")
os.system('npm i')
os.system('node cli/index')

#Get most recently downloaded video name
os.chdir("../tiktok-downloader/downloads")
get_file_name = subprocess.check_output("ls -t | head -n 1", shell=True)
name_of_file = get_file_name.decode('utf-8').strip()

# Name is currently just a giant string of integers. Ex: 7215600292283403566.mp4
new_name = input("\nName the file (w/o extension): ")

new_name = new_name if new_name.strip() else name_of_file[:-4] #get rid of .mp4 extension

# Rename file
os.system(f"mv {name_of_file} \"{new_name}\".mp4")

# Move the file
os.chdir("../..")
os.system(f"mv ./tiktok-downloader/downloads/\"{new_name}\".mp4 ./tiktoks/")

# Open finder to ensure it was downloaded correctly.
os.system(f"open -a Finder ./tiktoks/")

If you're getting an error that starts with "Error: SyntaxError: Unexpected end of JSON input" simply try rerunning the program.

If you're still getting the error that starts with "Error: SyntaxError: Unexpected end of JSON input" the endpoint might have expired. Go to the original repo here and copy the value for API_URL. Then go to your local cloned tiktok-downloader repo's "index.js" file and see if the API_URL is up to date. If not, paste the new one as the new value for API_URL in your local repository.

Results.instruction: Now yt-dlp should be properly installed. In the next steps we'll setup my CLI tool.
Install the following 3 Python libraries. You'll need these installed for the script.
Create the following directories.
Change into the directory and create new python file named "yt_downloader.py".
Past the following code into the "yt_downloader.py" file.

Results.CopyCode:
"""
This program is a command line interface tool for the
"yt-dlp" library. It allows you to download entire
youtube videos, download specific intervals of the
video and rename the mp4 file you're downloading.
"""

import os; os.system('clear')
import re
import subprocess
from pytube import YouTube
from termcolor import colored as c
import inquirer

save_dir = "a_songs_folder"
# save_dir = "Youtube_videos"
#save_dir = "Other_Youtube"

CURRENT_DOWNLOAD_PATH = f"../{save_dir}/"

if os.path.exists(CURRENT_DOWNLOAD_PATH):
	os.system(f"open -a Finder '{CURRENT_DOWNLOAD_PATH}'")
	print(f"{c('CURRENT DOWNLOAD PATH', 'magenta')}: {os.path.abspath(CURRENT_DOWNLOAD_PATH)}/")
	print("Finder has been opened to current download path. See updates in real time.")
else:
	print(c(f"\nPath does not exist: \"{CURRENT_DOWNLOAD_PATH}\"", 'red'))
	print(f"Go and create \"{CURRENT_DOWNLOAD_PATH}\" folder\n")
	exit(0)

def time_to_seconds(time) -> int:
	""" Converts int seconds to formatted time. """
	t = [int(x) for x in time.split(":")]
	return t[1] + (t[0] * 60) if (len(t) == 2) else t[2] + (t[1] * 60) + (t[0] * 3600)

def seconds_to_time(seconds) -> str:
	""" Converts seconds to minutes """
	if seconds < 60:
		return f"0:{seconds:02}"
	elif seconds < 3600:
		minutes = seconds // 60
		seconds %= 60
		return f"{minutes}:{seconds:02}"
	else:
		hours = seconds // 3600
		seconds %= 3600
		minutes = seconds // 60
		seconds %= 60
		return f"{hours}:{minutes:02}:{seconds:02}"

def get_choice(the_message):
	green_yes = c("Yes", 'green')
	red_no = c('No', 'red')

	print()
	questions = [
		inquirer.List('choice',
					message=the_message,
					choices=[green_yes, red_no]
					),
	]

	answers = inquirer.prompt(questions)
	return answers

url = input(f"\nEnter {c('youtube link', 'red')} : ")

video_len = YouTube(url).length

print(f"Video length is {c(seconds_to_time(video_len), 'cyan')}")

message = f"Do you want to download a {c('specific time interval', 'blue')} (y/n) ? "
is_time_interval = get_choice(message)

#'\x1b[32mYes\x1b[0m' the color made the string weird
if "Yes" in is_time_interval['choice']:
	print("\nThe format has to be (00:00:00) or (00:00). Ex: 3:12:11 or 8:07 or 21:32")

	start_time = input("\nEnter a start time: ").strip()

	while time_to_seconds(start_time) > video_len:
		print("\nInvalid start time")
		start_time = input("Enter a start time: ").strip()

	end_time = input("Enter an end time: ").strip()

	while time_to_seconds(start_time) > video_len:
		print("\nInvalid end time")
		end_time = input("Enter an end time: ").strip()

	download_length = seconds_to_time(time_to_seconds(end_time) - time_to_seconds(start_time))

	print(f"\nLength of download will be -> {c(download_length, 'blue')}\n")

	new_name = ""

	rename_message = f"Do you want to rename the file? {c('(y/n)', 'red')} "
	do_rename = get_choice(rename_message)

	if "Yes" in do_rename['choice']:
		name = input("\nNew name of file (without extension): ")
		new_name = f'-o "{name}.%(ext)s"'
		print(f"File's new name is {c(name, 'blue')}{c('.webm', 'blue')}")

	print()
	download_with_time = get_choice("Ready to download? ")

	if "Yes" in download_with_time['choice']:

		os.chdir(CURRENT_DOWNLOAD_PATH)

		print()

from flask import Blueprint, jsonify, request
import requests
from config import CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SECRET
from get_access_token import get_access_token

routes_blueprint = Blueprint('routes', __name__)

@routes_blueprint.route('/search', methods=['POST'])
def search():
	album_title = request.form.get('album_title')
	access_token = get_access_token(CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SECRET)
	headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"}
	search_url = "https://api.spotify.com/v1/search"
	search_params = {"q": album_title, "type": "album", "limit": 1}

	try:
		search_resp = requests.get(search_url, headers=headers, params=search_params)
		search_resp.raise_for_status()
		search_results = search_resp.json()
		albums = search_results.get('albums', {}).get('items', [])

		if not albums:
			return jsonify({"error": "No albums found with that title."}), 404

		selected_album = albums[0]
		album_id = selected_album['id']
		album_name = selected_album['name']

		tracks_url = f"https://api.spotify.com/v1/albums/{album_id}/tracks"
		tracks_resp = requests.get(tracks_url, headers=headers)
		tracks_resp.raise_for_status()
		tracks_data = tracks_resp.json()
		tracks = [track['name'] for track in tracks_data['items']]

		return jsonify({"album_name": album_name, "tracks": tracks})
	except requests.exceptions.RequestException as e:
		return jsonify({"error": "Failed to fetch data from Spotify API."}), 500

Results.CopyCode:
import requests
import json
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

load_dotenv()

CLIENT_ID = os.getenv('CLIENT_ID')
CLIENT_SECRET = os.getenv('CLIENT_SECRET')
REDIRECT_URI = os.getenv('REDIRECT_URI')
AUTH_CODE = os.getenv('AUTH_CODE')


def get_access_token(authorization_code):
	token_url = "https://www.linkedin.com/oauth/v2/accessToken"
	payload = {
		'grant_type': 'authorization_code',
		'code': authorization_code,
		'redirect_uri': REDIRECT_URI,
		'client_id': CLIENT_ID,
		'client_secret': CLIENT_SECRET
	}
	response = requests.post(token_url, data=payload)
	access_token = response.json().get('access_token')
	return access_token


def get_profile_data(access_token):
	profile_url = "https://api.linkedin.com/v2/userinfo"
	headers = {
		"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"
	}
	response = requests.get(profile_url, headers=headers)
	profile_data = response.json()
	return profile_data


def main():
	access_token = get_access_token(AUTH_CODE)
	profile_data = get_profile_data(access_token)
	print("Your account information")
	print(json.dumps(profile_data, indent=2))

if __name__ == "__main__":
	main()

Results.title: AWS Services We'll Use
Results.desc: These are AWS services we'll use and explanations of what they do.

Results.instruction: <u><b>EC2</b></u> - This stands for "Elastic Cloud Compute". This service allows you to create a virtual computer in the cloud. We're basically renting a terminal for free and running a python script on it.
<u><b>Secrets Manager</b></u> - This is the service we'll use to securely store the secrets for our project. We'll have to make changes to our script before we deploy it to incorporate this service.

<u><b>IAM</b></u> - This service will be used to help connect to the EC2 host on a local terminal. You probably already completed all the necessary steps for this service when you set up your AWS account.

Results.title: Store Secrets in AWS Secrets Manager
Results.desc: Explains how to use AWS Secrets Manager to store secrets for your project.

Results.title: Create an EC2 instance
Results.desc: Explains how to create an EC2 instance in the AWS console.

Results.CopyCode:
import praw
import smtplib
import boto3
import json
import os
from termcolor import colored as c
from botocore.exceptions import ClientError, NoCredentialsError
from email.mime.multipart import MIMEMultipart
from email.mime.text import MIMEText
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()

def get_secret():

	secret_name = "my-key"
	region_name = "us-east-1"

	aws_access_key_id = os.getenv('AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID')
	aws_secret_access_key = os.getenv('AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY')

	session = boto3.Session(
		aws_access_key_id=aws_access_key_id,
		aws_secret_access_key=aws_secret_access_key,
		region_name=region_name
	)

	client = session.client(
		service_name='secretsmanager',
		region_name=region_name
	)

	try:
		get_secret_value_response = client.get_secret_value(
			SecretId=secret_name
		)
	except ClientError as e:
		raise e

	secret = get_secret_value_response['SecretString']

	secret_dict = json.loads(secret)

	keys = [
		'CLIENT_ID',
		'CLIENT_SECRET',
		'USER_AGENT',
		'SENDER_EMAIL',
		'SENDER_PASSWORD',
		'EMAIL_RECIPIENT',
		'REFRESH_TOKEN'
	]

	secret_values = {key: secret_dict.get(key) for key in keys}

	return secret_values

def error_message(msg):
	print(c(msg, 'red'))

	if "AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID" in msg:
		print(c('export ', 'magenta'), end='')
		print(c('AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=your_access_key_id', 'blue'))

	if "AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY" in msg:
		print(c('export ', 'magenta'), end='')
		print(c('AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=your_secret_access_key', 'blue'))

	exit(0)


# Get Secret
try:
	secrets = get_secret()
except NoCredentialsError:
	error_message('Set your "AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID" and "AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY" environment variables')
except ClientError:
	error_message('Set your "AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY" environment variable')
except TypeError:
	error_message('Set your "AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID" environment variable')

# Your Reddit credentials
CLIENT_ID = secrets['CLIENT_ID']
CLIENT_SECRET = secrets['CLIENT_SECRET']
REFRESH_TOKEN = secrets['REFRESH_TOKEN']
USER_AGENT = secrets['USER_AGENT']

# Your Email Credentials
sender_email = secrets['SENDER_EMAIL']
sender_password = secrets['SENDER_PASSWORD']
email_recipient = secrets['EMAIL_RECIPIENT']

# Name of Subreddit you're working with. No "r/" in name. AskReddit is good for testing
subreddit_name = 'NAME_OF_SUBREDDIT'


reddit = praw.Reddit(
	client_id=CLIENT_ID,
	client_secret=CLIENT_SECRET,
	refresh_token=REFRESH_TOKEN,
	user_agent=USER_AGENT
)


subreddit = reddit.subreddit(subreddit_name)

def send_email(title):

	subject = f"Someone posted in r/{subreddit_name}!"

	body = (
		f'The title of the post is "{title}".\n\n\n' + 
		"This was sent from you're deployed reddit bot."
	)

	message = MIMEMultipart()
	message["From"] = sender_email
	message["To"] = email_recipient
	message["Subject"] = subject

	message.attach(MIMEText(body, "plain"))

	try:
		server = smtplib.SMTP("smtp.gmail.com", 587)
		server.starttls()
		server.login(sender_email, sender_password)
		text = message.as_string()
		server.sendmail(sender_email, email_recipient, text)
		server.quit()
		print("Email sent successfully!")
	except Exception as e:
		print(f"Failed to send email. Error: {e}")

def main():
	print(f"Monitoring new posts in r/{subreddit_name}...")

	for submission in subreddit.stream.submissions(skip_existing=True):
		print(f"\nSomeone made a post titled: \033[94m{submission.title}\033[0m")
		send_email(submission.title)


if __name__ == "__main__":

	if subreddit_name == 'NAME_OF_SUBREDDIT':
		print('\033[91mChange value of "subreddit_name" variable in script.\033[0m')
		exit(0)

	main()

Find the name of your flash_drive by running the following commands. In the output of the "ls" command you should see a volume named something like "USBMST1". Copy and record the name
Move back to your root directory using the following command

Now run the following command. In the output look for the name of the flask drive that you copied in step 1. Then copy and record the value under the "IDENTIFIER" categrory in the same row as your Flask drive name. It should look something like "disk8s1".

Now open the "flash_drive.py" file and paste in the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
import json
import os
import shutil
import subprocess
import time
from termcolor import colored as c

class FlashDrive:
    """ 
    Class to perform various flash drive operations

    Methods 
    open_flash_drive_in_finder: Opens flash drive path in Finder 
    add_file_to_flash_drive: Adds a file/folder to the flash drive
    delete_file_on_flash_drive: Deletes file from flash drive
    unmount_drive: Unmounts drive from computer 
    remount_drive: Remounts drive from computer 
    eject_drive: ejects drive from computer 
    get_all_files: Gets all the files from the flash drive as a list.
    explain_unmount_and_eject: Explains the difference between unmounting and ejecting a Flash Drive.
    
    Example code at the bottom of this file.
    """

    def __init__(self, flash_drive_name: str, flash_drive_identifier: str):
        """
        Initializes the flash drives path and identifier 
        :param flash_drive_name: Name of the flash drive ex: USBMST1
        :param flash_drive_identifier: Identifies the flash drive to eject it. Ex: /dev/disk4
        """
        self.flash_drive_path = f"/Volumes/{flash_drive_name}"

        # Flash drive identifier. Find this path using the command: diskutil list
        self.flash_drive_identifier = flash_drive_identifier


    def open_flash_drive_in_finder(self):
        """
        Opens flash drive directory in Finder. If error 
        occurs because flash drive can't be found print the 
        error in red.
        """
        command = ["open", self.flash_drive_path]
        result = subprocess.run(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, text=True)

        if result.returncode != 0:
            print(c(result.stderr.strip(), 'red'))
        else:
            print(c("Flash Drive's Content is being displayed in Finder!\n", 'blue'))


    def add_file_to_flash_drive(self) -> None:
        """
        Adds a file/folder to the flash drive.
        """

        while True:
            file_path = input("Please enter the path of the file/folder you want to add (or 'q' to quit): ")

            if file_path.lower().strip() == 'q':
                print(c("Operation cancelled.", "red"))
                time.sleep(1)
                os.system('clear')
                print_menu()
                return

            if os.path.isfile(file_path) or os.path.isdir(file_path):
                print(c("File/folder path is valid.", "green"))

                confirm = input(f"Are you sure you want to add \"{file_path}\" to your flash drive? (yes/y): ")

                if confirm.lower().strip() in ["yes", "y"]:
                    break
                else:
                    print(f"The file/folder will {c('NOT', 'red')} be added to your flash drive. Please enter a new path.")
            else:
                print(c("Invalid file/folder path. Please try again.", "red"))

        file_name = os.path.basename(file_path)
        destination_path = os.path.join(self.flash_drive_path, file_name)

        try:
            if os.path.isfile(file_path):
                shutil.copy(file_path, destination_path)
            elif os.path.isdir(file_path):
                shutil.copytree(file_path, destination_path)

            print(c(f'The file/folder: "{file_name}" was successfully added to the flash drive. Destination: "{destination_path}"', "green"))
            self.open_flash_drive_in_finder()
        except Exception as e:
            print(c(f'An error occurred while trying to add the file/folder to the flash drive: {str(e)}', 'red'))


    def delete_file_on_flash_drive(self) -> None:
        """
        Deletes a file or folder from the flash drive.
        """

        while True:
            self.open_flash_drive_in_finder()

            all_files = self._get_files_recursive(self.flash_drive_path)
            
            if not all_files:
                print(c("\nThere are currently no files or folders on your Flash Drive.", "red"))
                return

            file_path = input("Please enter the path of the file/folder you want to delete (or 'q' to quit): ")

            if file_path.lower().strip() == 'q':
                print(c("Operation cancelled.", "red"))
                time.sleep(1)
                os.system('clear')
                print_menu()
                return

            file_name = os.path.basename(file_path)
            destination_file = os.path.join(self.flash_drive_path, file_name)

            if os.path.exists(destination_file):
                confirm = input(f"Are you sure you want to delete \"{file_path}\" from your flash drive? (yes/y): ")

                if confirm.lower().strip() in ["yes", "y"]:
                    try:
                        if os.path.isdir(destination_file):
                            shutil.rmtree(destination_file)
                        else:
                            os.remove(destination_file)
                        print(c(f'The file/folder: "{file_path}" was successfully removed from the flash drive!', 'green'))
                    except Exception as e:
                        print(f'Error occurred while trying to remove the file/folder from the flash drive: {str(e)}')
                else:
                    print(f'The file/folder: "{file_path}" will {c("NOT", "red")} be deleted. Please enter a new path.')

            else:
                print(c(f"Can't delete the file/folder: \"{file_path}\". Does not exist on flash drive.", 'red'))


    def unmount_drive(self) -> None:
        """
        Unmounts the flash drive from the computer without full on 
        ejecting it. 
        """

        try:
            command = ['diskutil', 'unmountDisk', self.flash_drive_identifier]
            result = subprocess.run(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, text=True)
            
            if result.stderr.strip():
                print(c(result.stderr.strip(), 'red'))
            else:
                print(c(f"Flash drive at '{self.flash_drive_identifier}' has been successfully unmounted!\n", 'green'))

        except Exception as e:
            print(c(f'Error occurred while unmounting the flash drive: {str(e)}', 'red'))

    def remount_drive(self):
        """
        Remounts the flash drive. Prints an error
        if process can't be completed.
        """

        try:
            command = ['diskutil', 'mountDisk', self.flash_drive_identifier]
            result = subprocess.run(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, text=True)
            
            if result.stderr.strip():
                print(c(result.stderr.strip(), 'red'))
                print(c("Make sure you've physically removed your flash drive after the last ejection.\n", 'red'))
                exit(0)
            else:
                print(c(f"Flash drive at '{self.flash_drive_identifier}' has been successfully remounted!\n", 'green'))
        except Exception as e:
            print(c(f'Error occurred while remounting the flash drive: {str(e)}', 'red'))

    def eject_drive(self) -> None:
        """
        Ejects the flash drive from the computer.
        """

        try:
            command = ['diskutil', 'eject', self.flash_drive_identifier]
            result = subprocess.run(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, text=True)
            
            if result.stderr.strip():
                print(c(result.stderr.strip(), 'red'))
                print(c("Make sure to connect and mount your Flash Drive.\n", "red"))
                exit(0)
            else:
                print(c(f"Flash drive at '{self.flash_drive_identifier}' has been successfully ejected!", 'green'))
                print(c("Physically remove the flash drive from your computer to eject it completely.\n", 'blue'))
                exit(0)

        except Exception as e:
            print(c(f'Error occurred while ejecting the flash drive: {str(e)}', 'red'))
            exit(0)

    def get_all_files(self) -> [str]:
        """
        Gets all files from the drive and returns them as a string list. Doesn't include 
        hidden files.
        """
        try:
            if not os.path.exists(self.flash_drive_path):
                print(c("The specified flash drive path does not exist.\n", "red"))
                exit(0)

            all_files = self._get_files_recursive(self.flash_drive_path)

            if all_files:
                print("\nThese are all the Files on your Flash Drive:")
                for file in all_files:
                    print(file)
            else:
                print(c("\nThere are currently no files on your Flash Drive.", "red"))
                
        except Exception as e:
            print(f'Error occurred while getting files from the flash drive: {str(e)}')


    def _get_files_recursive(self, path, level=0):
        """
        Helper function to recursively get files and folders.
        """
        items = []
        try:
            for entry in os.listdir(path):
                if not entry.startswith('.'):
                    full_path = os.path.join(path, entry)
                    indent = '    ' * level

                    if os.path.isdir(full_path):
                        items.append(f"{indent}{entry}")
                        items.extend(self._get_files_recursive(full_path, level + 1))
                    else:
                        items.append(f"{indent}- {entry}")

        except Exception as e:
            print(f'Error occurred while accessing the path {path}: {str(e)}')

        return items
    
    def copy_file_to_new_location(self, old_file_name, new_path):
        """
        Copys a file from the flash drive to a new location
        :param old_file_name: The name of the file on the flash to be copied.
        :param new_path: The new path the file will be copied to.
        """
        fd_file_path = f"{self.flash_drive_path}/{old_file_name}"
        os.system(f"cp {fd_file_path} {new_path}")

    def explain_unmount_and_eject(self):
        print("\nDefinitions")
        print(f"{c('Unmount', 'blue')}: Temporarily disconnect the Flash Drive logically, but not physically. Do this if you plan to reconnect Flash Drive without physically removing it first.")
        print(f"{c('Eject', 'blue')}: Logically and Physically remove the Flash Drive\n") 
        
        understood = input("Understood? (y/yes): ")

        if understood.lower().strip() in ["yes", "y"]:
            print(c("Great!", "green"))
            time.sleep(1)
            os.system('clear')
            print_menu()
            return

def print_menu():
    print("Flash Drive Options")
    print("1. Open flash drive contents in Finder ")
    print("2. Add files/folders to your flash drive")
    print("3. Delete files from your flash drive")
    print("4. Unmount your flash drive")
    print("5. Remount your flash drive")
    print("6. Eject flash drive from your computer ")
    print("7. Displays all the files from your flash drive")
    print("8. Explains unmounting vs ejecting a Flash Drive\n")


def choose_option(flash_drive, choice: int):
    match choice:
        case 1:
            flash_drive.open_flash_drive_in_finder()
        case 2:
            flash_drive.add_file_to_flash_drive()
        case 3:
            flash_drive.delete_file_on_flash_drive()
        case 4:
            flash_drive.unmount_drive()
        case 5:
            flash_drive.remount_drive()
        case 6:
            flash_drive.eject_drive()
        case 7:
            flash_drive.get_all_files()
        case 8:
            flash_drive.explain_unmount_and_eject()
        case _:
            print(c("Invalid number", "red"))


def get_flash_drive():

    with open("data.json", "r") as file:
        content = json.load(file)
        
    name = content['Name']
    identifier = content["Identifier"]

    return FlashDrive(name, identifier)


def prompt_user(flash_drive):
    while True:
        user_input = input("Choose an option 1-8 (or 'q' to quit): ")
        
        if user_input.lower() == 'q':
            print(c("Program quite successfully", "green"))
            flash_drive.eject_drive()
            break
        
        try:
            user_number = int(user_input)
            if 1 <= user_number <= 8:
                choose_option(flash_drive, user_number)
            else:
                print(c("Invalid input. Please enter an integer between 1 and 8.", "red"))
        except ValueError:
            print(c("Invalid input. Please enter an integer between 1 and 8.", "red"))


def main():

    flash_drive = get_flash_drive()

    print_menu()
    prompt_user(flash_drive)

main()

Results.instruction: This is how you run a webpage with a Python Server backend. This was inspired by Dr. Layman's examples in CSC 351. I would strongly recommend using Flask over this approach, but I was curious what he was doing in class and if it had good use cases. The only real difference between what he did and what I did, is that he used SQLite3 and I used a more SQLAlchemy based approach. If you kept your old CSC 351 assignments, you can see more in-depth examples of a Python Server in "security-deposit-web-yourgithubusername". If you have questions hmu.
First open your terminal and run the following command.
Create a folder for your server.
Change into your "server" directory.
Create the following files in your "server" folder.

touch server.py
touch database.py
touch models.py
touch handler.py

Results.instruction: In the "server.py" file paste the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
import socketserver
from handler import CustomHandler
import os

os.system('clear')

PORT = 8080

with socketserver.TCPServer(("", PORT), CustomHandler) as httpd:
	print(f"Serving at port ", end="")
	print(f"\033[94mhttp://localhost:{PORT}/\033[0m")

	httpd.serve_forever()

Results.instruction: In the "database.py" file paste the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
from sqlalchemy import create_engine
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base
from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker

DATABASE_URL = 'sqlite:///items.db'
engine = create_engine(DATABASE_URL, echo=True)
Base = declarative_base()
Session = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
session = Session()

def init_db():
	from models import Item
	Base.metadata.create_all(engine)

Results.instruction: In the "models.py" file paste the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, Sequence
from database import Base

class Item(Base):
	__tablename__ = 'items'
	id = Column(Integer, Sequence('item_id_seq'), primary_key=True)
	name = Column(String(50))

Results.instruction: In the "handler.py" file paste the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
import http.server
import json
from database import session, init_db
from models import Item

class CustomHandler(http.server.SimpleHTTPRequestHandler):
	def do_GET(self):
		if self.path == '/items':
			self.send_response(200)
			self.send_header("Content-type", "application/json")
			self.end_headers()

			items = session.query(Item).all()
			items_list = [{"id": item.id, "name": item.name} for item in items]
			self.wfile.write(json.dumps(items_list).encode('utf-8'))
		else:
			super().do_GET()

	def do_POST(self):
		if self.path == '/add-item':
			content_length = int(self.headers['Content-Length'])
			post_data = self.rfile.read(content_length)
			data = json.loads(post_data.decode('utf-8'))

			new_item = Item(name=data['name'])
			session.add(new_item)
			session.commit()
			self.send_response(200)
			self.send_header("Content-type", "application/json")
			self.end_headers()
			response = {"message": "Item added successfully", "id": new_item.id}
			self.wfile.write(json.dumps(response).encode('utf-8'))
		else:
			self.send_response(404)
			self.end_headers()

init_db()

Results.instruction: Create a server.js file.
Open your "node_server" folder in VSCode and paste the following code into the "server.js" file.
Open a new terminal, change back into your folder and run the server.

Title: How to Populate a SQLite3 Database üìä

Results.title: How to Populate a SQLite3 Database
Results.desc: This is an extremely basic way to populate a SQLite3 Database with Python and JSON

Results.instruction: Since sqlite3 is included in the standard library of python you don't need to download anything.
Make a folder called test_db. Then create two files to create and populate your table. Also create a json file to store data.

Results.CopyCode:
mkdir test_db
cd test_db
touch create_db.py
touch populate_db.py
touch cars.json

Results.instruction: Open the "create_db.py" file and paste in the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
import sqlite3

conn = sqlite3.connect('Cars.db')

cursor = conn.cursor()

cursor.execute('''
	CREATE TABLE Cars (
		Maker VARCHAR(20),
		Color VARCHAR(20),
		Year INT
	);
''')

conn.commit()
conn.close()

print("\033[92m" + "Cars table successfully created!" + "\033[0m")

Results.instruction: Open the "populate_db.py" file and paste in the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
import sqlite3
import json

with open("cars.json", 'r') as file:
	contents = file.read()
	data = json.loads(contents)

conn = sqlite3.connect('Cars.db')

cursor = conn.cursor()

for car in data['Cars']:

	maker = car["Maker"]
	color = car["Color"]
	year = car["Year"]

	sql = 'INSERT INTO Cars (maker, color, year) VALUES (?, ?, ?)'

	cursor.execute(sql, (maker, color, year))

conn.commit()
conn.close()

print("\033[92m" + "Cars table successfully populated!" + "\033[0m")

Results.instruction: Open the "convert.py" file and paste the following code.

Results.CopyCode:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')

with pd.ExcelWriter('output.xlsx', engine='xlsxwriter') as writer:
	df.to_excel(writer, index=False, sheet_name='Cars')

	workbook = writer.book
	worksheet = writer.sheets['Cars']

	date_format = workbook.add_format({'num_format': '0'})

	worksheet.set_column('C:C', None, date_format)

Also note the comments and variable naming conventions and casing. Learn more here -> https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html.

Results.Name: Properly Formatted Python file
Results.Description: This is a properly formatted Python file. Note the use of whitespace around the if-else and for-loop blocks. Also note the comments. Learn more here -> https://peps.python.org/pep-0008/.
Results.CopyCode:
# Name: Michael Totaro
# Date: 10/24/2022
# Purpose: Create and demonstrate CarList class (Not a real assignment).
# collaborators/resources: None other than Dr. Pence

class Car:
	""" This class is a basic car object. """
	def __init__(self, car_id, company, year, color, miles):
		"""
		Initializer for a Car object.
		:param id: Id of the car
		:param company: Maker of the car
		:param year: Year car was made
		:param color: Color of the car
		:param miles: Miles driven by the car
		"""
		self.id = car_id
		self.company = company
		self.year = year
		self.color = color
		self.miles = miles

	def __str__(self):
		"""
		Creates a string representation of a car object.
		:return: string representation of a car object.
		"""
		car_str = (f"\nCar {self.id}\n"
				   f"Company: {self.company}\n"
				   f"Year: {self.year}\n"
				   f"Color: {self.color}\n"
				   f"Miles: {self.miles}")

		return car_str + "\n"


class CarList:
	"""
	This class is data structure of car objects.
	You can add, remove, and print the list.
	"""
	def __init__(self):
		"""
		Initializes an empty car list
		"""
		self.car_list = []

	def add_car(self, new_car):
		"""
		Adds a car to the car list if conditions are met.
		:param new_car: Car object to be added to the list
		:return: True if the car was added successfully else false.
		:raises ValueError: If parameter is not an instance of a car object
		"""

		if not isinstance(new_car, Car):
			raise ValueError("Parameter must be an instance of a car object.")

		for car in self.car_list:
			if car.id == new_car.id:
				print(f"A car in the list already has the id '{new_car.id}'!")
				return False

		self.car_list.append(new_car)

		return True

	def remove_car_by_id(self, car_id):
		"""
		Removes car in the list by id.
		:param car_id: The id of the car to be removed.
		:raises ValueError: If parameter is not an int.
		"""

		if not isinstance(car_id, int):
			raise ValueError("car_id must be an integer.")

		for car in self.car_list:
			if car.id == car_id:
				self.car_list.remove(car)
				print(f"Car {car_id} removed successfully!")
				return

		print(f"No car with the id {car_id} was found!")

	def __str__(self):
		"""
		Creates a string representation of a CarList object.
		:return: The cars in the list as a string
		"""
		return "\n" + " ".join([str(car) for car in self.car_list])

	def __len__(self):
		"""
		Get the length of the car_list
		:return: The length of the car list
		"""
		return len(self.car_list)


def main():
	"""
	The driver code to test the CarList class.
	"""
	car_list = CarList()

	car_list.add_car(Car(1, "Honda", 2012, "gray", 12430))
	car_list.add_car(Car(2, "Toyota", 2005, "black", 25430))
	car_list.add_car(Car(3, "Ford", 1999, "red", 19430))

	try:
		car_list.add_car("This is a string object")
	except ValueError as e:
		print(e)

	car_list.add_car(Car(1, "Used id", 1999, "red", 19430))

	print(f"Length of list before you remove a car {len(car_list)}")

	car_list.remove_car_by_id(1)

	print(f"Length of list after you remove a car {len(car_list)}")

	car_list.remove_car_by_id(100000)

	print(car_list)

main()
