Results.desc: These are more general tips I have for school and life in general.

Results.tip: No matter what I'm working on, it always seems like the hardest part of it is getting started. I find that I sometimes procrastinate when I find a task daunting or think it will be challenging. It's never as bad it seems once you get started and get into the flow of things. Just try your best to start working on what you find difficult and it's usually not nearly as hard as you think it will be. Relevant Mark Goatberg clip.

This is kind of adding the first point, learn the 5 second rule. Whenever you have something to do and are procrastinating, don't just sit there and ponder about it. Start counting down from 5 and when you get to 1, make a decision about what you're going to do. For example, say I've been scrolling on Instagram for a while and have work to do. I'd start counting down from 5 and once I get to 1 I'll decide if I should keep scrolling or go do something more productive. It works basically everytime.

The beauty of UNCW's campus is extremely underrated imo. App State and UNC tend to get all the attention. However, UNCW has some really nice, very big hiking trails I used to walk somewhat frequently. It's a great way to get exercise and unwind at the same time. I also think it'd be a fun activity to do with your friends. The trails I'm referring to are behind Seahawk Landing, though I'd typically start at a different point.

Results.underlined: Send in your high school AP scores
Results.tip: If you haven't done so already, I'd recommend sending in your high school AP scores. They can get you college credit which can be beneficial for many reasons. The credit can help you graduate early, get out of classes you don't want to take, give you more time to take classes you do want to take, etc.
Internships are a great way to develop skills and gain experience. It also looks good to future employers who are looking for someone with past experience.
It's normal to think that everyone knows more than you, or is more experienced than you. Don't be afraid to ask for help or feel lesser of yourself. People will typically be happy to help you learn.

Results.underlined: Keep up to date with you emails
Results.tip: Sometimes emails contain important information that requires your attention. I'd recommend checking and cleaning your emails consistently to keep up with important info.

Whenever I had to give a presentation in college it always seemed like people were missing a cable to hookup their computer to the smartboard. I think cable adapters are a great thing to have to charge multiple devices at once, hookup to smartboard, etc. I'd recommend buying this one that you can buy from your older brothers company Amazon. It's a little pricey but definitely worth it imo. Just make sure to buy one that actually works for your computer.
Your GPA doesn't have to be perfect, but companies usually ask what your GPA is using ranges. The top range is usually 3.5 and above, so try to maintain that.

Obviously if you think this would be too heavy a workload, you don't have to take this many credit hours. However if you want to graduate early taking 21 credits in a semester might help you. I did this a couple times in college and it allowed to me graduate a semester early. Contact your counselor for an override.

Results.underlined: Buy your diploma frame from the UNCW bookstore
Results.tip: The bookstore sells diploma frames. When you graduate it's a good place to look since they have the right sizes.

Results.underlined: Have a .txt file on your computer paste information
Results.tip: Having a single text file you can temporarily put information in has been useful in my experience. You can shrink it and quickly copy, paste, and delete info while you're working. You can have it open right beside whatever you're working on.

Results.underlined: Network and meet people at your job
Results.tip: Networking is a great way to meet new people and gain new opportunities.
This is a relatively affordable way to get from Wilmington to Charlotte if you don't have a car.

Results.underlined: Follow Lil Goof Ball on TikTok
Results.tip: This guy went to UNCW and I think his TikTok is pretty funny. You can follow him here. Also, he's on campus pretty frequently, so keep an eye out for him if you want.
Finishing one task at a time can help keep you focused and organized on what you're working on.

Having a well-organized and professional looking resume can help you stand out to employers. I've gotten a couple compliments on my resume from recruiters before. See this page for the template I use.

Results.underlined: It's not too late to change major, or add a minor
Results.tip: If you wanted to switch to computer science, or add a CS as a minor it's not too late. I outlined classes you be taking in this [page](/Classes/CompSciMinor). If you switched you could also use some of the classes you've probably already taken for a business concentration/minor.
College clubs are great way to meet people with similar interests as you.

Results.underlined: Know how to present a powerpoint project with notes on zoom
Results.tip: To share your presentation on zoom without showing your audience the presenters notes watch this video. First open your powerpoint presentation, then on the right-side of the bottom bar, click on the icon that says "Slide Show" when hovered over and click on it. Then in the lower left-hand side click on the icon with three dots, in the pop up menu select "Use Presenter View". Now go back to zoom using control + up arrow (if you‚Äôre on mac). When you're back on zoom click "Share" and select the screen that says "Microsoft PowerPoint - PowerPoint Slide Show" or something similar when hovered over. Then click "Share", you should be good now.

Results.desc: These are phone apps that I'd recommend doing. I chose them based on how useful and enjoyable they are to use.
Results.desc2: These are apps that I think would be worth downloading.
Results.email: Email yourself all these download links.
Results.desc3: These are popular apps that you have probably already downloaded.

Results.Name: Genius Scan
Results.Description: Used to Scan papers using your camera and turn them into pdfs. Recommended by one of my old math professors at UNCW. I found it extremely useful when I was in college. Would highly recommend.

Results.Name: LinkedIn
Results.Description: I think it's good to use the app to see notifications, job alerts, etc. I also feel like the app is a little easier to use than the website.

Results.Name: ChatGPT
Results.Description: Super useful for obvious reasons.

Results.Name: Handshake
Results.Description: This is the app UNCW uses for job searching. It's like their version of linkedin.

Results.Name: Alarmy
Results.Description: This is the alarm app I use. I really like the UI, the sound it uses, and the overall features.

Results.Name: Coursicle
Results.Description: Allows you to track the open status of courses. Will send you a notification when a class goes from closed to open.

Results.Name: Waze
Results.Description: This is the GPS app I use. It's extremely useful when driving. It can calculate the most optimal routes and redirect you if you go the wrong way.

Results.Name: SafeZone
Results.Description: This is the new app UNCW uses to send out alerts about hurricanes and stuff as of August 2024.

Results.Name: Google Maps
Results.Description: I feel like this is a good app to use a Walking GPS. I prefer Waze for driving though.

Results.Name: GitHub
Results.Description: Can be used to help with authentication and allows you to access your repositories on your phone.

Results.Name: Microsoft Teams
Results.Description: My CSC 450 used this app to communicate during the class in a similar way to Slack.

Results.Name: Uber
Results.Description: You probably already know what this is, but I'll describe it anyway. It's basically a taxi service app. You can order an uber/taxi at basically ANY location and it will come pick you up and drive you around. This was very helpful when I needed to get a drug test for my job when I was in Wilmington and didn't have a car. I also think the UI is super cool which is a bonus. Would definitely recommend it.

Results.Name: AllTrails
Results.Description: This is a search tool to find hiking trails in your area. You can find trails and leave reviews.

Results.Name: PayByPhone Parking
Results.Description: If you ever go somewhere that has paid parking, this is a really good app to have. It seems to be the most widely used app for paid parking.

Results.Name: AWS Console
Results.Description: Allows you to easily see billing and information about running services.

Results.Name: Amtrak
Results.Description: This is an app for finding trains. While I wouldn't find it useful if I lived in Wilmington, I do find it very useful in RTP. You can sometimes get places faster, cheaper, safer, etc. than in an uber. I use it to get from Durham to Charlotte.

Results.Name: Canvas
Results.Description: Manage your UNCW assignments, view grades, future assignments, etc.

Results.Name: Duo Mobile
Results.Description: Used for two-factor authentication at UNCW and many other places.

Results.Name: Microsoft Outlook
Results.Description: Manage your UNCW email and other outlook emails

Results.desc: These are various computer science and programming-related things I like.
Results.desc2: These are various computer science related things I like.
Results.desc3: These are code snippets that show syntax and functionality I like.

Results.description: A project called "plane-notify" created by Jack Sweeney. This video does a really good job describing what it is. It's basically a bot that tracks Elon Musks jet. It's written python and you can see the source code here. Also, Jack Sweeney accepted my connect request on Linkedin which is pretty cool.

Search bars. Ever since I started coding I've had a somewhat strange fascination with search bars. It seems like they're everywhere but people still have difficulty implementing them in their projects. That's why I made sure not to "cheat" the search bar functionality in this project (it was originally supposed to be a box pop-up thing). Search bars can be extremely useful in your project and I'd recommend implementing them wherever you think they'd be helpful.

Steve Jobs talking about programming. In this video Steve Jobs talks about how he thinks everyone should learn to code. I like the point he makes about how programming teaches you how to think in the real world. I often find myself using Java syntax to describe real-life events in my head.

GitHub pages. I love GitHub pages and it's where this website is currently being hosted. It allows you to host any static website for free which I find very convenient as my websites usually don't use databases or dynamic rendering.
Pushing to GitHub. I like the feeling of pushing code to GitHub and have it successfully working. I find it satisfying.
Visual Studio Code is the main text editor I use. I find it very versatile and I use it in basically all my programming tasks. I'd strongly recommend downloading it and trying it out.

The UNCW Computer Science curriculum. I think UNCW has a great CS curriculum that allows for a lot of creativity and flexibility. It also teaches you a diverse spectrum of skills which will help prepare you for the real world.
Markdown. I really like markdowns syntax and I find it convenient when creating ReadMes. I took inspiration from markdowns syntax for the hyperlinks in this project.
Emailjs. This is a JavaScript library that allows you send emails for free. I used it in the "Contact Me" page in this project. Here's the link to set it up.
The "termcolor" library. This is a Python library that allows you to color the text in your terminal output. I find it very useful to differentiate between messages and I think it looks nice.

Results.Description: This is a great way to create and populate a list in Python.

Results.Name: Ternary Operator
Results.Description: Condensed if-else statement. Appears in Java, JavaScript, C++, Swift, etc.

Results.Name: ForEach Loops/Arrow Functions
Results.Description: ForEach loops act like a regular for loop. Arrow functions have concise syntax

Results.Name: Nil-Coalescing Operator
Results.Description: If name isn't null, set "unwrappedValue" to that value. If name is null set to "Anonymous". Appears in JavaScript, TypeScript, Swift. Note it's called "nullish" in JavaScript and TypeScript.
Results.CopyCode:
let name: String? = nil
let unwrappedName = name ?? "Anonymous"

let ternaryEquivalent = (name != nil) ? name : "Anonymous"

Results.Name: File Reading
Results.Description: Python's file reading syntax is easily my favorite part of the language. So simple and useful.

Results.Name: JavaScript Object Notation
Results.Description: JSON Objects are extremely useful for transferring data around. It's like a simplified class. YAML and XML are too jank in my opinion. You can think of a json file as a list of Python dictionaries or strings.

Results.Name: Try/Catch Block
Results.Description: I *LOVE* the try/catch/throw syntax in Java. It's just a vibe. I use this syntax to describe real life events in my head all the time.

Results.Name: Dictionaries and F-Strings
Results.Description: Python dictionaries are basically the same as JSON objects but I still love them. Also, they're very fast and you can look items up in O(1) time. F-strings are great way to format strings with variables in them and add values of different data types to a string. I also really like the for-loop syntax to iterate over a dictionary/JSON object.
